title: qasem soleimani jeremy corbyn rod liddle
story: This quote sprang to mind when I read about the Iranian military boss Qasem Soleimani being evaporated by a very large missile sent by the Yankees.“Bang!” went the missile — and no more Qasem. Do I feel diminished, I wondered, very briefly Nah, I concluded, sod that. Good shot. And good riddance. I felt no more regret than when I squash a tick from my dog’s back.Soleimani was a vile man. He orchestrated terrorist attacks which caused death, misery and mayhem for millions across the Middle East and beyond.He was in Iraq planning attacks against our own forces as well as American ones. And he was doing so in the service of a country which has a pretty good claim to being the worst in the world — Iran.Hell, even North Korea can’t match Iran for its support of worldwide terrorism and the multiple murders in Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Israel and Yemen.Iran is a pariah state, a thoroughly odious religious dictatorship, under which homosexuals are executed, Christians and Jews persecuted.Where there is no freedom of speech, no freedom of conscience, no freedom for women to wear what they want or do what they want.An economically wrecked Stone Age nest of barbarians whose government has spent the past  years waging war against anyone and everyone — but largely, it has to be said, other Muslim nations.Oh, and shoring up its malign influence across the whole of the wretched Middle East. And trying very hard to develop nuclear weapons so it can cause even more devastation — mainly to the area’s only democracy, our ally Israel.No wonder, then, that Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour leader, has a soft spot for Iran. It hates us — and therefore the deluded halfwit is on its side. Asked about the killing of Soleimani, he denounced the USand refused to accept that Soleimani was a terrorist.Meanwhile, so-called “experts” have been suggesting Donald Trump’s missile strike will increase tensions and could even lead to a Third World War.What rubbish. As my dad might have put it, Iran doesn’t have a pot to p**s in.The same experts were saying Iran would wait and carefully consider its options before launching some devastating attack. Wrong, wrong again.It waited about half an hour before lobbing a bunch of crap rockets at US bases, which killed no American soldiers at all, according to reports.I’m not in favour of getting involved in the Middle East’s politics, unless they are targeting our people or our interests.I was against the invasion of Iraq and against the bombing of Libya. Against our involvement in Syria, too.But here was a clear case where an agent from a hugely hostile foreign government was fomenting trouble in a country — Iraq — full of US and British troops.One missile got rid of him. Another might get rid of whoever takes his place. Countries such as Iran need to know that the tide has turned. We won’t put up with their continual sponsorship of terrorism.Especially in the north of the country. This month the TransPennine service is cutting almost HALF of its trains, causing havoc for commuters. It’s offered passengers with a season ticket a three-per-cent rebate. Brilliant.Meanwhile, Northern Trains is about to be stripped of its franchise. About time. The service I use looks like it was dug up from a disused railway line in Czechoslovakia in about . South Western Railway is in trouble, too.Here’s what to do. Take them into public ownership. It’s one of the few Labour policies that the public liked. And it would prove that this is a government which will act even when it’s against the Conservative instinct.And then scrap HS and spend the money on improving the rolling stock and infrastructure between our great northern cities.Sound like a plan, Mr Johnson and Mr Cummings ENJOYING the Labour leadership contest  Never has the party seemed so hilariously irrelevant.One of the frontrunners, Rebecca Long-Baileywas asked what she thought of Jeremy Corbyn’s election campaign. She said she gave it “ten out of ten”. And kept a straight face.The worst performance in  years. Rebecca, love, the people voted in just  Labour MPs. That means they gave Corbyn less than three out of ten for his campaign. Meanwhile, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan is hoping to be deputy leader. Heard of her  Nope, me neither.She has suggested we should have a Ministry of Fabulosity, where “fabulous MPs” think up “fabulous things”. She also suggested that instead of a debate, MPs could have a Strictly-style “dance-off, because we all love a boogie”.Is she six years old  Or just out of her brainbox on horse tranquilisers This is the party, remember, that gave Britain the National Health Service, welfare state and decent education. And its leadership is being contested by people with the combined IQ of a tub of BQ tile grout.Ha.The brilliant Russian comedian Konstantin Kisin has a good answer to that: “If the Russians had been involved in Brexit, it wouldn’t have taken more than three years. It would have been one meeting – we’re out. And we’d have taken a big chunk of France with us.”TERRIBLE news. The left-wing journalist Owen Jones has announced he will be cutting back dramatically on the time he spends talking utter b*****ks on Twitter.What on earth shall we all do  I hope the Government might set up a counselling service for those of us grief-stricken by Owen’s decision.He does have a point, mind. Twitter is a moronic institution. It reflects the views of a tiny proportion of the people and is largely filled with obsessive maniacs shrieking abuse at each other.Twitterstorms, as they call them, matter less than a handful of dust.They are just maniacs, from the left or right, desperate to be outraged.Do yourself an even bigger favour, Owen, and leave Twitter entirely.I CAN’T quite get into Veganuary. I’ve tried – I ate some peas the other night, for example.But I can’t be doing with the ious supplements vegans have to take to stop them dropping dead.Also, vegan sausages taste like the seat lining from a Toyota Corolla.Instead, then, I’ve decided to embrace Januhairy. This is where women stop shaving their front bottoms and end up with vast thickets of undergrowth in which deer and rabbits frolic with gay abandon.Now, I was never in the habit of shaving down near my old fella. Not least in case the razor slipped. But there’s plenty of surplus hair I did keep in check – poking out of my nostrils, hanging down from my ears and sprouting from my eye-brows. I’m going to leave all that alone for a month.Soyou see an overweight northerner coming towards you, who looks like a cross between Hagrid and Denis Healey, you’ll know it’s me.IT’S Bafta time again and of course there’s the usual moaning about a lack of ersity in the nominations. Why no black actors  Why no female directors The answer to these questions might be that on this occasion the judges reckoned the best performances came from actors who happened to be white, and directors who happened to be men.Equality does not mean every single thing in our lives should be made up of an equal proportion of black people, disabled people, gay people, women and so on.Some harridan even had a go at Margot Robbie because she was nominated twice and happens to be white. Get real, you race-obsessed bores.And good luck to the lovely Margot. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu chief waste time brexit red lines
story: We welcome Ursula von der Leyen being “ambitious” about striking a new, “unprecedented” trade deal with “zero tarfs and zero quotas”.We too want to remain “the best of friends and partners”. But we implore Brussels not to expend energy hoping to erode Boris Johnson’s Brexit red lines.Without them he would not have his -seat majority. And he simply has no desire to soften Brexit. Britain will not be bound by Brussels.Yes, goods will flow less freely at our borders. That is the price of freedom and the many new opportunities this Government, unlike the last, looks ­genuinely keen to exploit.Even Remainers like Bank of England chief Mark Carney and ex-Chancellor George Osborne say our hands must not be tied by EU regulations over finance.For Boris that holds true for everything  too.THE IRA, Putin, now Qasem Soleimani. Without fail, Corbyn takes our enemies’ side.It’s not hard to condemn Soleimani as a terrorist. It’s not “siding with Donald Trump” to do so. But Corbyn can’t.What concerns him is not eliminating the architect of Iran’s slaughter across the Middle East — the monster who killed British and US troops. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry face calls to pay back £.m spent on their official home after revealing their bid for financial independence from the Royal Family. A Privy Counsellor and campaign group Republic criticised the Duke and Duchess of Sussex for saying they would step down as senior royals - but keep a claim on the newly-refubished Windsor pad. In a statement last night the Royal couple said they would step back as ‘senior’ members of the Royal Family and work to become financially independent, iding time between the US and UK.But they added they will continue to use Frogmore Cottage ...as their official residence as they continue to support the Monarchy, and so that their family will always have a place to call home in the UK.The cottage was renovated at a cost of £.m of public money between November  and March  - refurbishing and renovating five residential units to create an official residence for the couple. The refurbishment was paid for by the Sovereign Grant - a sum of money given to the Monarch from the Government which was £.m in  . The Grant is calculated based on profits from the Crown Estate, and would not have been lowerthe Royal Family had decided to spend the money for Frogmore Cottage on something . However, the Sovereign Grant is still officially allocated by the government - a sort of aposallowanceapos for the Monarch. Graham Smith, chief executive of the campaign group Republic, suggested the promise of financial independence rang hollow.He said: Itaposs not just Frogmore Cottage - theyaposre going to be relying on the politan Police to provide security.And they are going to be relying on their official title to cash in and make a profit on those official titles that they hold.  I certainly think they owe the taxpayer a refund. They have spent £.m on refurbishing their house on the taxpayer. It was going to be their home and now theyaposve decided to live where so we need that money back. They need to abandon their claim to that house. Former Lib Dem minister Norman Baker, one of hundreds of privy counsellors who advise the Queen, said the pair should repay the money. Mr Baker - who lost his seat in  - said: The taxpayer has spent millions on Frogmore Cottage for the couple on the understanding that Harry and Meghan intended to be working royals. Now they have changed their minds, Harry should repay the money spent on the house to the taxpayer. As he is worth at least £million and probably much more, and Meghan is a millionaire in her own right, they can easily afford to do so.  In general the royal family is far too large and expensive so it needs to be slimmed down. In that sense Harry and Meghanaposs decision to give up senior royal status is welcome. We need others in the royal family to follow suit and reduce the massive cost to the taxpayer.Former Labour MP Emma Dent Coad, who lost her seat last month, said: While my feelings about the institution of monarchy are very well known, clearly this young couple want to start afresh.And it would be a gesture of good faith to the public to show that they mean what they say by reimbursing the public purse for the renovation of a home that theyaposre never going to live in. People come to me with ceilings collapsing, black mould going through the walls. Their heating and plumbing doesnapost work. And the public spent £.m on renovating somewhere theyaposre not going to live in.

The Commons will be in recess for  working days this year - not including conference season and the Christmas break, which has yet to be announced.Itaposs the most days of downtime since , before Brexit seized control of the Parliamentary agenda. The bumper breaks mean Boris Johnson will have to fewer sessions of Prime Ministeraposs Questions and ministers wonapost have as many departmental questions sittings.It will give Parliamentary committees less time to scrutinise Government decisions through the year. Sarah Clarke, a spokesperson for Unlock Democracy said this “squeezing of scrutiny” could not come at a worse time. At  working days, MPs summer holiday this year will be the longest since . Many MPs use the recess to catch up on constituency work - but they are free to use the time as they wish. The average holiday entitlement for British workers is . days.  But even the bumper break available to MPs wasn’t enough for one senior Tory. title: harry two strong women life
story: NewsopinionHarry had two strong women in his le - and he chose Meghan over the QueenThe Queen protected Harry and William after the death of their mother Princess Diana. She was criticised for looking after the poor boys instead of mourning in publicShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JAN NewsopinionThe Queen was drawn to Harrys impish sense of humour " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn the early hours of August , , the Queen sat in her dressing gown at Balmoral Castle beside a sobbing Prince of Wales. They had just been informed, via a call from Paris, that Princess Diana had been killed in a car crash. Despite being numb with shock, the monarch’s first thought was to protect her grandsons William and Harry, whose lives were about to implode. She persuaded Charles to wait until morning before breaking the shattering news and ordered that all radios, TVs and newspapers be removed to shield the young princes. Then, rather thanto London to mourn with her subjects, she stayed closeted in her castle and tried to support “those poor boys”. It was one of the rare occasions when the Queen put family before duty – yet it led to a national outcry and accusations that she was distant, unfeeling. But it also sparked a touching new relationship with Diana’s boys and a special affinity with -year-old Harry, so patently damaged by his mother’s death. “Granny” became the most important female role model in his le until he met his future we Meghan. His nanny Tiggy-Legge Bourke was the cuddly surrogate mum – but the Queen was a counsellor, adviser and inspiration. She shared his love of country pursuits, his passion for the military and his impish sense of humour. Who can forget them both glowing with pride at Harry’s Sandhurst passing- out ceremony in  or the cheeky looks between them in the video he persuaded her to make to promote his Invictus Games in   “I absolutely adore my grandmother,” he said in an interview marking her th birthday, “but I always view her as the Queen – the boss.” When viewing footage of the -year-old Princess Elizabeth pledging her le to the service of the Commonwealth, he declared: “It’s a hugely moving speech.  “It’s incredible to know that someone at that age appreciated and understood exactly what was expected of them. To basically put duty ahead of everything  so early in her le is quite remarkable.” But Harry seemed to have an equally strong sense of duty, serving his country in the Army then forging a role as a Commonwealth Youth Ambassador with his new bride Meghan Markle . Ah yes – Meghan, the “breath of fresh air” we all took to our hearts when we saw how she had captured Harry’s. The orced, mixed-race, US actress and humanitarian who would aid the monarchy’s modernisation and give Harry the family and sense of purpose he craved. No wonder the Queen looked so delighted when the Duke and Duchess introduced her to their baby Archie. Poor lost Harry had found his other half, his happy ever after. So how can it be that, eight months on, he appears to have totally lost the plot  How could he have defied his Granny – his “boss” – with such callous disregard for her feelings, not to mention those of his father and brother  The -year-old Queen is left feeling angry, wounded and betrayed by the Sussexes’ arrogant attempt to create their own brand of royalty.  A move apparently prompted by the pair’s perception that Meghan has been “bullied”, “hounded” and “vilied”. When it looks to be more about her need to own the limelight, rather than take second billing to future Queen Kate and for them both to make a fortune out of Hollywood-style celebrity status while playing at saving the planet. Harry is so besotted with his older, charismatic, psychobabble-spouting we that it seems his personality is subsumed into hers. This fun-loving bloke has become the Prince of Woke and, while Meghan may have opened his eyes to many important issues, you can’t help feeling he has lost his sense of self. A former friend of his told me: “We all know people who’ve met a new partner and begun to distance themselves from old pals and relatives, becoming part of the other’s circle. “But when Meghan got engaged to Harry she cut herself off from family and old mates – and the only friends at their wedding were her A-list celebrity ones. “Now she and Harry are cutting themselves off from his family – yet expect to keep all perks and privileges, because being royal is their big selling point.

The couple held a series of heart-to hearts after agreeing they “couldn’t continue under the microscope of royal le”. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex put their plan into overdrive in the last six weeks after speaking to advisors linked to Hilary Clinton and Oprah Winfrey, before pressing the nuclear button on their royal careers. They kept the developments from the Queen, Prince Charles and Harry’s brother William while enlisting the help of a select band of advisors in the UK and America. The result to effectively resign from ‘The Firm’ and announce their new path without consultation has been met with “dismay and fury” inside the palace walls.  A well placed palace source said: “This all stems from their tour in South Africa. “Harry was the driving force behind it and was adamant there was no way back. He saw Meghan was struggling and told her he didn’t want to do another tour with the press and they would go their own way. “Meghan had already made the moves with contacts in America to launch their ‘brand’ and provided the avenue for it to happen. “After just  months of marriage, it was decided they couldn’t continue under the microscope of royal le and would leave on their terms.” The couple stopped communicating with their press team in the UK and instead launched their strategy to ditch their royal roles opening the door for them to earn millions in the corporate world. Sources say they will now split their time between the UK and Canada and are even considering home schooling their eight month old son Archie when he is ready. They have suggested they will dramatically scale down the number of official royal engagements on behalf of the Queen and instead turn the focus onto developing their personal foundation. Here we look at the obstacles that may face them as their embark on their new royal le: MONEY:    Harry and Meghan are worth £million in their own right and yet still received public funds from the Sovereign Grant. Harry was left £ million from his late mum Princess Diana’s estate and around £million from the Queen mother when she died. He also receives an yearly allowance from Prince Charles while Meghan was a successful TV actress before she met Harry. The Sovereign Grant is collected from the profits of Queen’s property portfolio - the Crown Estate - which are paid to the Government. Twenty-five per cent of these profits are paid to the monarchy to fund the upkeep of its property, travel, security and staff.  More than £. million was used from fund to do up their lavish Frogmore Cottage home, while the run their offices and pay for their travel on official engagements. The couple still plan to carry out some engagements on behalf of their team but have not yet devised a way of paying for it - unless they start signing mega-money deals with big corporations. Harry also receives up to £.million annually from his father’s royal estate, the Duchy of Cornwall. Palace aides have refused to say whether he will continue to take the money, which suggests the couple’s claims of being “financially independent” are far from clear. Senior palace sources say there is “huge implications of them entering the corporate world on their own accord” and the couple have not explained how they see this working. SECURITY:    Meghan and Harry have “failed to answer the simplest of questions” relating to their security provision, according to well places sources. They expect they will keep their state-funded politan Police protection officers who are paid for by the Home Office - with the bill topping £,-a-year. With overtime, travel and accommodation expenses this would likely reach £million. The issue of the Sussexes splitting their time between the UK and North America has given “major headaches ” to government departments on both sides of the Atlantic. Again, it is understood Harry and Meghan have not come up with suggestions as to how their security would be paid for. THE ADVISORS:  The couple have been working with the controversial US PR company Sunshine Sachs and will launch the Sussex Royal Foundation in the coming months. They employed the Clinton’s former communications advisor, American Sara Latham, last year. Stan, who trained at the ­codebreakers’ HQ Bletchley Park during the Second World War and went on to serve with the RAF and later at a ‘listening post’ in Hong Kong, is not one to complain, but his feet are hanging off the edge of the trolley. “I grew up in the years before the NHS was set up, when healthcare was ‘hit and miss’,” Stan says. “My ­generation built the NHS to take the worry out of being ill, and to make sure that everyone has access to good quality healthcare.” Yesterday shocking new figures showed a record collapse in ­emergency care across the NHS – with Stan just one of tens of thousands of people left on trolleys. In December, the number of people waiting four hours or more on hospital trolleys reached , while , people waited more than  hours. Both figures are the highest on record. Stan is at pains to stress how “caring the staff are and how hard they work for their patients”. But he says they are “overworked and stressed”.Health Secretary Matt Hancock visited the hospital on December  – the day before the general election – to “see the impact that the new AE has had, just incredible impact”.But by December , when Stan faced his -hour ordeal, the election was over and the spotlight had faded.Election victor Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already on a £,-a- week holiday on the private island of Mustique. Some , miles away back home, Stan lay on a trolley. Born in , he grew up in the East End of London. “He was evacuated during the war, but like many children ed just in time for the doodlebugs,” his daughter Rachael Ellis, a social worker, says. “His own home experienced bomb damage with Stan and his family living in half a house until they could move where.” Stan has had an ­incredible le, eventually becoming a teacher, studying for a PhD in retirement and has been married for  years to Bette. But now, he needs the support of the NHS. On December , paramedics rushed him to hospital after he became very unwell with a suspected infection. He was admitted to AE just before midday. From .pm until pm there was a power cut, caused by an underground cable fault, which meant some ambulances were erted to other hospitals and that some equipment couldn’t be used. “AE was packed, with people sitting on the floor,” says Stan’s ­granddaughter Roxanne Ellis, a Labour and Co-operative councillor. “Staff were having not only to reassure distressed patients and family members but also cope without  their usual back up and information.  “We were told there was no bed available for Stan. He was fth on the list of older people waiting for a bed and th overall. While Stan did not complain – that’s not in his nature – he was clearly very uncomfortable. “The trolley wasn’t long enough, his feet were hanging over the edge and he kept sliding further down needing assistance to get back. Meanwhile, he was steadily getting more poorly and became delirious. “We don’t want to criticise NHS staff, who in our view were doing an amazing job under very dficult circumstances. The only reason the NHS hasn’t failed has been due to the overwhelming commitment of the staff.” Jonathan Ashworth MP, Labour’s Shadow Health Secretary, is also the local MP for Leicester Royal Infirmary. “Stan’s case is yet another heart-breaking example of how our NHS has been plunged into total crisis under the Tories,” he says. “Years of cutbacks mean unacceptable misery for patients like Stan who deserve so much better. “The worst AE figures on record and almost , patients waiting on trolleys is a badge of shame for the Tories.

title: dee must bounce back and secure second spot says keeper hamilton
story: Dundee goalkeeper Jack Hamilton insists it is vitally important they quickly bounce back from defeat to Inverness and secure second spot in the Championship.The Dark Blues fell to fourth in the table after a - defeat to second-placed ICT at Dens on Saturday and now lag six points behind the Highlanders.Sitting in the final promotion play-off spot is far from where the Dee would have hoped to have been at this stage of the season.However, Hamilton admits they can only look at themselves to recty that and make their path to any potential push for Premiership promotion clear as early as possible.“You don’t want to be coming towards the end of the season wondering where you’ll finish. Ideally, we’ve got to be finishing second,” he said.“It takes out that extra two games in the play-offs and that’s where we want to be, that’s what we’re looking towards and realistically we’ve got the squad to do that.“We’ve got to look to win every game and it’s down to us really. Dundee United are sitting  points ahead so,they weren’t to win the league it’d be a disaster on their part.“We’ll just concentrate on ourselves. There’s no point looking at anybody , each week we don’t look at other results thinking ‘whatwe do this and that’ we just focus on our own performances and how we’re going to beat teams.“We need to start getting three points on the board again.”Ending their four-match unbeaten run, particularly after a morale-boosting derby draw the weekend previous, with a loss against the Caley Jags stung for Dundee and Hamilton.And the -year-old is determined to put that right as soon as possible with three points when third-placed Ayr United come to town on Saturday.The former Hearts man added: “It was really disappointing off the back of a good run of games and it just wasn’t acceptable.“We started sloppy and it just continued throughout. It wasn’t a nice one on Saturday.“In the derby, in the second half in particular, I thought the boys were magnicent and then you’re looking for the same as that against Inverness on Saturday but we started off poorly and that just continued throughout the game. vw, px"  “We knew what they were all about, they’re sitting second in the league and they’re a good side.“They were a team we had to beat but we’ll sit down and watch the game and we’ll see where we went wrong.“We’ve got to recty that in the next game looking forward.“We just need to get back to the second half of the derby, that’s the performance we’re capable of and we’ve got a right good team in that dressing-room – it’s just about getting that consistency and kicking on from there.“Everybody out there on the pitch knows how good we are inidually so it’s one of those ones where we are frustrated.Dundee - Inverness: Dismal Dee drop to fourth with ICT defeat" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee---inverness-dismal-dee-drop-to-fourth-with-ict-defeat embed # secretXqUmxEai" data-secret"XqUmxEai" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“We need to assess the game and look to see where we can improve.“Going forward, we need to get the three points against Ayr.”And Hamilton knows they need to get the fans back on side after many voiced their displeasure on Saturday.“It’s not nice and you can feel and understand the supporters’ frustration.“They’re entitled to their opinion, quite rightly so because they support the team.“They want the highest possible achievement for Dundee and likewise so do we, so when things aren’t working out as we’d like they’re going to be frustrated.“We’ve got to do it for them as well as ourselves.”

title: dundee 0 2 inverness dismal dee drop to fourth with ict defeat
story: Dundee dropped to fourth in the Championship table as they fell to a - defeat to Inverness at Dens Park.First-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings did the damage as John Robertson#s Caley Jags strengthened their grip on second spot.Ayr winning at Dunfermline meant the Dark Blues dropped to the fourth and final promotion play-off spot,  points behind leaders Dundee United.Dee boss James McPake stuck with the same line-up which earned a point in the Dundee derby with -year-old Fin Robertson starting in the middle of the park after a terric display at Tannadice.Inverness were the first to threaten but Nikolay Todorov could only head Miles Storey#s cross over the bar after three minutes.Caley skipper Carl Tremarco went closer on nine minutes as he got on the end of another Storey cross after a period of pressure. However, Dark Blues keeper Jack Hamilton gathered the header comfortably.Hamilton then made a smart stop from a whipped Keatings free-kick minutes later as the visitors continued to push for the opener.On  minutes Charlie Trafford forced a routine save out of Hamilton before, just a minute later, Inverness got the goal their play deserved.In acres of space down the right, full-back Shaun Rooney had the freedom of Dens Park to pick out Doran in the centre of the box and the Irish attacker duly lashed home from  yards.On  minutes, ICT were two to the good. From their own corner, Dundee compounded to lose possession and allowed the Highlanders to break.Former Dundee United man Keatings led the charge and finished the counter attack off himself, coolly slotting beyond a helpless Hamilton in the home goal.The Dark Blues huffed and puffed for the remainder of a dismal first half for them but were unable to lay a glove on Inverness as the boos rang out among the sizeable home support on the half-time whistle.Four minutes into the second period, Dundee forced Mark Ridgers into his first save of the afternoon as the ICT goalie stooped to turn Jordan Marshall#s long-range effort behind for a corner.Jordan McGhee was next to test Ridgers, firing in a dipping effort just before the hour mark, but the Caley stopper was able to gather.Moments later, Paul McGowan#s header from a deep Sean Mackie cross forced Ridgers to tip over as the Dee sought a way back into the contest.On  minutes, Kane Hemmings laid in Marshall but the left-back saw his effort from  yards deflected behind.Inverness# front four continued to look threatening but, largely, the Dee defence kept them quiet in the second .However, McPake#s men were unable to carve a way through an organised ICT defence with the rookie boss cutting a frustrated and under-pressure figure throughout.With Ayr and Dunfermline to face next, Dundee will certainly need to perform a lot betterthey are to stay in the mix for the promotion play-offs come the end of the season.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, Meekings , McGhee, Marshall Robertson, Dorrans, McGowan, MackieJohnson , Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Byrne, Moore and Cameron.Inverness XI : RidgersRooney, Donaldson, McHattie, TremarcoTrafford , Vincent StoreyKeatings Doran Todorov .Subs not used: Mackay , McCart, Curry and MacGregor.Referee: Don Robertson.Att: ,.

title: harry and meghan to step down as senior royals how do you feel about the monarchy
story: News that Prince Harry and his we Meghan Markle are step back as ‘senior’ members of the royal family and work to become “financially independent” has caused controversy at a time when the monarchy comes under increased scrutiny.The royal family are said to be #hurt# at the Duke and Duchess of Sussex#s announcement they will step back as senior royals.Prince Harry and Meghan did not consult any senior royal before making the statement, it is understood # including Harry#s grandmother, the Queen, or his father Prince Charles, heir to the throne.The statement from Prince Harry and Meghan said: “After many months of reflection and internal discussions, we have chosen to make a transition this year in starting to carve out a progressive new role within this institution.“We intend to step back as ‘senior’ members of the royal family and work to become financially independent, while continuing to fully support Her Majesty the Queen.“It is with your encouragement, particularly over the last few years, that we feel prepared to make this adjustment.“We now plan to balance our time between the United Kingdom and North America, continuing to honour our duty to the Queen, the Commonwealth, and our patronages.“This geographic balance will enable us to raise our son with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born, while also providing our family with the space to focus on the next chapter, including the launch of our new charitable entity.“We look forward to sharing the full details of this exciting next step in due course, as we continue to collaborate with Her Majesty The Queen, the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and all relevant parties. Until then, please accept our deepest thanks for your continued support.”Buckingham Palace responded saying: #Discussions with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are at an early stage.#We understand their desire to take a dferent approach, but these are complicated issues that will take time to work through.#The news comes just weeks after Prince Andrew gave what was widely regarded as a #car crash# interview where he denied allegations he had a sexual relationship with an underage girl, linked to a paedophile engaged in sexual traffickingThe Duke of York said in an interview with BBC Newsnight in November he met the late Jeffrey Epstein in , through Epstein’s former girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell .Convicted sex offender Epstein procured many women, including underage girls, who were then sexually abused by Epstein and some of his contacts.Epstein killed himself in August last year.Maxwell, the daughter of press baron Robert Maxwell, has been accused by a number of women of being complicit with Epstein in sex trafficking and abuse and, in some cases, partaking in it. She has denied all allegations against her.Prince Andrew is alleged to have had sex with Virginia Roberts Giuffre for the first time at Maxwell’s London home.Giuffre alleges she had sex with the prince when she was aged  on the instructions of Maxwell.Andrew claims to have “no recollection” of meeting Roberts Giuffre, despite being pictured with his arm around her in a now notorious photograph said to have been taken by Epstein.Roberts Giuffre allege she and Andrew had sex three times.In the aftermath of the interview, and following a number of charities and organisations he supported distancing themselves or removing their association with him, Prince Andrew announced he would be stepping down from royal duties #for the forseable future#.With The Queen#s son and grandson no longer undertaking #senior# royal duties, the Tele is interested to know how our readership view the monarchy.Please vote in our poll below.

title: youth prospect declan glass has sights set on permanent role in dundee united first team
story: Dundee United’s latest youth import hopes while form is temporary, Glass is permanent at Tannadice.Nineteen-year-old Declan Glass made histo the Tangerines first team at Queen of the South on Saturday after being recalled from loan at Cove Rangers.And he has his sights firmly set on a prolonged spell in the first team after his first appearance since September .He told the Tele: “I’ve been on two loans, to Airdrie last season and right away to Cove this time, so it has been a while – it doesn’t feel like that long, to be honest.“I’m delighted to be back. Dundee United is where I want to be, where I want to be playing so it was really good to be back on Saturday.“To get recalled early gave me a boost going into the weekend’s game and to go straight into the team was a bonus.“Then to get three points, I’m delighted.“I found out the start of last week I was coming back.“The gaffer spoke to me and I went up to Cove just to say bye to the boys.“Paul Hartley spoke to me and told me to keep doing what I had done up there at United.“The gaffer here has emphasised that as well – hopefully, I took my chance on Saturday.”Glass shone in League Two as Cove lead the way at the top of the table, scoring seven goals in  appearances and winning the ision’s Player of the Month award in August.The teenager s to the club with United sitting pretty,  points clear of the rest of the Championship and on the back of an -match unbeaten run that’s brought  victories.And he feels the spell at the top of League Two with the Aberdeen club will serve him well as he s to Tannadice.He added: “I was still in at United every day during my loan and working under the gaffer so I’ve come into the team in a good position, knowing what the gaffer expects.“It’s going to be a huge second half to the season.“It’s going to be all about consolidating our league position and pushing for the title.“It’s about getting as many points on the board as possible and trying to wrap things up as quickly as possible.“It was like for like at Cove, we were battling away at the top of the table there, too.“I think it probably helped me going out to a club like that where we were pushing for promotion as well.“To come back to United in this position is nice, to be fair!“I don’t think our lead means anything, though – we need to keep winning games and focus on each Saturday as it comes.”The next Saturday coming is another tough away trip to Partick Thistle.Ian McCall’s side are on an upward trajectory with three wins and a draw in their last five matches as they battle to get away from the foot of the table.Glass is targeting another start for the Tangerines at Firhill but knows they’ll have to be on their game to make it  wins from their last . vw, px"  “Partick are a big club and probably don’t think they should be where they are,” Glass added.“We are battling to win a league, they are battling for survival, which is maybe a surprise, so both teams have a lot to play for.“I expect another really tough game, another battle but, hopefully, we can come out on top.“Last weekend Queens were tough, they are always dficult away, they pride themselves on being a good home side.“Not many teams get three points there and I think we showed a dferent side of us, we can go to places like Palmerston and scrape wins.“I thinkyou want to win a title, that’s huge.”

story: An Aberdeen well engineering and project management company has seen an % increase in turnover in the past year.Zenith Energy, based in Bon Accord Square in the city centre, delivered more than £ million of contracts in the past  months.It is hoped that  will surpass that mark for the firm, which provides specialist expertise for the complete well le cycle.The company has seen some signs of recovery in the UKCS, with two projects in UK and Irish waters launched.Its Australia office, which was launched two years ago, also trebled in staff numbers to six and has turned over £.m – a % increase.Martin Booth, managing director of Zenith Energy, said the North Sea was still a target for the company.He said: “ has seen huge expansion for the company and it is long-term work which creates secure growth and stability to allow us to focus on future planning and development strategy and  is going to be equally as strong.“The North Sea is still a target for us as we know the market and there is a new wave of companies coming through now which are well placed to use well service experts like Zenith Energy.”The firm launched in the north-east in  and currently works with more than  clients in  countries.

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: hundreds of kids get helping hand from north east charity
story: A north-east social care charity has provided support to hundreds of children in the last year.VSA provided guidance and aid to youngsters with disabilities or experiencing situations such as a family breakdown.A total of  children were given one-to-one counselling, while  youngsters with additional support needs were also given help.VSA organised , visits through its dedicated contact centre, which helps children going through a family breakdown by helping them contact a parent they no longer live with.And the charity won six Scottish Qualications Authority awards last year for its work with young people.School-based counselling is another of the charity’s services, which operates at Northfield, St Machar and Hazlehead Academies.Anna Garden, VSA’s director of children and family services, said: “We work closely with families, the local authority and other third sector partners to determine need and deliver services across the city.“We work from a strengths-based approach and consult with children and families to shape the design and delivery of future service provision.“We also have a contact centre which provides supported contact for children who have been affected by parental separation.“Where there is initial acrimony after separation, the contact centre acts as a neutral venue to facilitate contact with the non-resident parents.”She added: “We also have services for children with disabilities – after-school care for children with disabilities – offering a higher staff ratio than the universal services. The after-school club provision allows wraparound care provision for children with disabilities so their parents can maintain employment.”Aberdeen City Council’s education convener Councillor John Wheeler praised the charity’s work with young people across the region.He said: “I fully recognise the importance VSA has across the city. The charity does tremendous work in all the dferent areas.”

title: thousands of tributes scotland superfan joe
story: A football fan who travelled across the globe to watch his beloved Scotland team play has had a “fitting tribute” paid to him.Joe McGunnigle died at his Aberdeen home on January  after being diagnosed with stage four head and neck cancer in .The -year-old followed the national team to five World Cups with trips to Germany, Spain, Mexico, Italy and France between  and .Joe even cycled from Aberdeen to Hampden when he was younger so he could join the ranks of the Tartan Army in Glasgow.In  he travelled east to Slovenia to watch a World Cup qualying match having recently had surgery.One item that always accompanied Joe on his footballing adventures was his red tartan jacket.He would always make sure he bought a patch featuring each country’s name and flag.Joe collected more than  badges and he sewed them on to the garment.Now the jacket has been donated to the Scottish Football Museum at Hampden Park in Glasgow where it will go on display.Joe’s daughter Karen Sedgwick said having it showcased at the museum was a “fitting tribute” to her late father, and she said despite his illness, his love for the beautul game did not diminish at all.Karen said: “He had a tartan jacket and everywhere he would go he would have a patch sewn on to it.“The Hampden football museum is going to put it on display.“It has  patches from dferent countries where he went to watch Scotland play.“It is a real fitting tribute for my dad to have the jacket on display at the football museum.“My dad was still watching football to the very end. He spoke about it all the time and his enthusiasm never waned.”Joe was one of the stars of a Friends of Anchor Brave fundraiser event in May , which saw him strut his stuff down the catwalk at a fashion show, clutching a board with the famous Doric phrase ‘haud gaun’written on it.In December , he also cut the first sods of turf at the Anchor Centre in the city, which will house all cancer treatments, including radiotherapy and oncology, under one roof in the future.As well as Scotland, Joe was also a fan of Aberdeen FC and amateur football club Woodside, a team he used to manage.Away from football he worked as an aircraft engineer at Aberdeen Airport and even ran his own kitchen company before his retirement. His we Cath died  years ago.Karen said tributes to her dad have been flooding in and have been a comfort for the family.She said despite his own struggles with cancer, he made sure everyone around him was smiling and that extended to all of the healthcare staff who helped him.Karen, of Midstocket, said: “We’ve had thousands of tributes and it is wonderful to see.“It has been so comforting. He loved people.“Even at the hospital with the doctors and nurses he kept everyone smiling.”Joe’s family took him on holiday and Karen even arranged for him to enjoy some horse riding during a recent trip to Aviemore.He also got to spend Christmas with his loved ones and even enjoyed a Guniness with his older brother to mark the beginning of .Karen said her father’s bravery in the face of his fight with cancer is something she will never forget.She said he was something of an inspiration for everyone he met.Karen continued: “I loved him for his straightforwardness and his courage.“He really set an example and a standard for us all.“For the Brave event, everyone had a motto on a board they took on the catwalk. I asked my dad what his would be and he said ‘haud gaun’.“It was his phrase and it epitomised my dad.”His granddaughter Cassie McGunnigle said her grandfather was a “major part” of all their lives.The Robert Gordon University student lived with him for  years and he had wanted to see her graduate after completing her events management degree course later this year.She said: “He was major part of our lives and always will be.“He gave a lot of people hope despite his illness.”Mr McGunnigle’s funeral service will take place at St Mary’s Cathedral on Tuesday.He is survived by his brother Frank, his three children Karen, Joe and Gary, eight grandchildren and six great grandchildren.

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Scottish Salmon Companyhas provided Cowal Badminton Association with funding towards new sporting equipment following its latest round of Community Fund awards.Cowal Badminton Association received a £ donation to cover the costs of rackets and shuttlecocks for their new practice nights.The association was founded almost  years ago, playing a vital role in bringing the community of Dunoon together by offering weekly social events that are inclusive to all.Development co-ordinator at Cowal Badminton Association, Craig Anderson, said: #The funding from SSC has enabled us to purchase new rackets and tubes of shuttlecocks, which our members will be able to use. We hope this will remove a barrier to new members joining, as they will no longer have to provide their own equipment. On behalf of the team, we thank the Scottish Salmon Company for its kind donation.#Volunteers are being offered a chance to work off some of the seasonal over eating, as a work party is held at Tarbert Castle.Meeting at am tomorrow , the group will set about planting trees and removing brambles until around lunchtime.The perfect opportunity to catch up following the festivities, all willing to help will be made welcome and tea and coffee will be on offer to the hard working volunteers.A #Scandinavian# approach to self-sufficiency is being proposed by Craignish Community Council.With Argyll and Bute Council being unable extend their gritting areas, community council members picked up bags of grit from the council depot. Four bags have been placed by the Glebe houses, five up Ardlarach Road on the pavement nearer the top and three for the steeper bits on the road up to Lunga.Empty bags can be handed into Ardfern Shop and they will be re-filled.In a Facebook post Craignish Community Council said: #It seems that in future we may be best taking the more Scandinavian approach of managing it ourselves for those areas beyond council gritting.#The weather was chilly but dry for the Boxing Day shinty match in Strachur, attracting a good number of spectators .In the annual under-s versus over-s clash, the old boys just about squeaked it - after an exciting match at Strachurmore Sports Centre.Veteran Ally Mirrlees opened the scoring with a well-taken goal just five minutes into the match. Ten minutes later Lewis Montgomery levelled matters, before another from Montgomery beat over-s keeper Ross MacDonald to give the youngsters a half-time lead slimmer than most of the waists in the opposition ranks.The game was to turn in the second half, as Neil Nicolson scored twice for the old boys and the victory was theirs, despite goalie Willie McGladdery pulling off some good saves for the under-s.The Niall Campbell Memorial Trophy was presented to winning captain Ross MacDonald by Mr Campbell#s son John, and a very sociable evening followed in the Strachurmore pavilion.PIC:All smiles after an entertaining match to blow away the festive cobwebs. no_aStrachurBoxingDay

title: a bumper year for rallying
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards was a big year for Argyll locals with the much anticipatedof one of the biggest events in Scotland on the doorstep, Mull Rally, and the continued running of the Mach  Stages and Argyll Stages in Dunoon. Three events all within a stones throw of Mid Argyll.Jamie Miller was the only local to enter this event, starting his Scottish Tarmac Rally Championshipcampaign for the year in the rapid  Citroen CR. Paul Hunter, swapping his pacenotes for spanners, was on hand to assist Jamie throughout the season. Conditions were said to have been tricky as Knockhill has its own micro-climate, which consists purely of rain, wind, snow, ice, wind and wind. Sadly it wasn#t to be at Knockhill for the team with mechanical failure ending their day after stage two.The first closed road event to take place in England, after the approval of closed road rallying for the UK, was the first event for the famousGTi. Unfortunately for Kirsty Mochrie her licence can only be upgraded to stage events from single venue use when she turns , so it was theof the pairing of Innes Mochrie and Paul Hunter to represent Mid Argyll south of the border. The pair, finding the conditions tricky in the narrow lanes after the top seed cars had been pulling mud from verges and ditches, managed to bounce the wee metro over the first loop of four stages until the gearbox had enough on the fth test.Following the cancelling of Inverness# Snowman Rally earlier in the year, this was now first round of the Scottish Rally Championshipfor Dougie Watt and Ian Parker, and it was interesting to say the least. A glance outside in the morning to see about four inches of snow lying on the roof of the MK Escort was a surprise for a start. A very wet and muddy day saw the pair make it to the finish in one piece which is more than can be said for the clutch cable that snapped about one mile into the final stage, however clinching their first class win of the season was the best start to the championship.With Kirsty #Wee Mo# Mochrie in the co-drivers seat in the rapid Corsa of Steven Hay , a fair pace was set by the pair throughout the day sitting as high as th until they unfortunately had to take a split early to save damaging the car. Back out the next stage and still setting a blistering top  pace in the Corsa, including some hang time on both the jumps.Jamie, back out in the fit C, had bad luck once again. This time an overshoot on a square right and a struggle to get the car started again after a stall sadly earned him a stage max on stage two. Still setting top  times on the day he ended nd which was a fair effort when you include a stage maximum time.Ian was out this time with Fraser #Flat oot Fraz# Smithafter winning an entry to the rally at the STRC Awards in January. Flying out the gates and onto their second lap on the first stage then pop, driveshaft burst. Towed in and sorted, both covered in CV Grease, they made it back out for a skid around and on a mission to tear up some old tarmac tyres.The Granite Stages, now held at RAF Leuchars would see Eoghan Anderson make ato the passenger seat for a hurl in the immaculate MK Escort of Martin Murray. Smiling ear to ear all day, with Bill eagerly awaiting histo the service area for the stage report, they finished th overall.Ian was out with Greg Inglisin his fluorescent Orange Lotus Exige and it was eyes on the prize for STRC points for Greg. A clean day saw Greg really getting to grips with the car on some surprisingly fast stages including a tickle of the limiter in fth saw the pair finish third overall.Back together and with the small repairs from the Speyside done it was time for the Furnace MK toto the woods. A steady run over the opening two stages, Dougie and Ian found their feet after the #off# at the Speyside sent them into service lying th. From seeing their overall position they knew they had to get back into it on the next stage, however on the road section to start stage three there was issues selecting gear and the pair decided to call it a day # damage limitation was the right call, as the input shaft was on its last legs.Jamie was back on the pace for this one, setting a th fastest stage time on the opening test. Sitting th overall heading into stage five was impressive given the competition on the day. Bad luck unfortunately, however, was to .Eoghan was again out with Martin in the MK for a blast. Sadly it was an early bath, retired after stage two but again, as always, enjoying every minute while it lasted.The Argyll rally had been known to have rough and challenging stages the previous two years. Not this time. Ian and Dougie couldn#t believe how good the stages were in comparison to previous years, an absolute joy of an event with the Escort not missing a beat all day on its #shakedown# for the big one. Valuable class points added to the scorecard too, with them ending the event nd overall. The rally had struggled with entries this year and will now run in  as a closed road rally, run by Mull Car Club.Team Mochrie were back together for this one in the Mightyagain and Innes was cutting some questionable shapes in the garage, performing his annual Mach rain dance. Taking chunks of time from his first passes of the stages would see them ring the #s neck and clinch th.Jamie#s luck had finally turned, the C singing all weekend and netting him a topper of th overall and th fastest over the final stage too.Duncan Maclean was back in the driving seat with Ian alongside, giving himself and the car a shakedown before Mull. The freshly rebuilt #blue bullet# was looking superb and managed to finish looking just as sweet. A couple of small teething problems were sorted on the day and the new main focus was to have power steering fitted before Mull # poor Dochy lost about a stone over two days with the effort needed to swing the wee pug around the #s and chicanes.In August Dougie and Ian competed on the Vetomies Rally. A national grade event run alongside the WRC Rally Finland event. Three other crews from Scotland also headed over to sample #the fastest rally in the world#. The stages were unbelievable. Fast, cresty, wide, flowing with a brilliantly smooth surface. The whole event was just surreal. The duo finished the event th overall and more importantly the fastest Scottish crew.Once the car had ed from Finland it was quickly jacked up, checked and loaded onto the trailer the same day for the journey north. Due to two DNFson the Speyside and Scottish, Dougie and Ian had to make the trip to be in with any chance of regaining their class lead in the SRC. Ending the day first in the class meant they were heading into the final round with the lead.Jamie was back out for another counting round of the STRC. Enjoying his day and pushing the wee C on in the blistering heat netted Jamie and co-driver Ian Mccullochrd overall. He must have been relaxed in the heat as in between stages he was off with the overalls and on with the baby lotion, topping up the tan.Ian was back out with Greg in the Lotus. Another fantastic drive from Greg, finishing ninth with the championship title race firmly the primary goal.The final round for the MK and an important one # a DNF here could see Dougie and Ian losing the class lead in the championship. A battle with their rival who they had been chasing all season, Paddy Munro, would come down to the last stage, as the pair were six seconds down on Paddy heading into the final test. Probably one of the duo#s best stages all year, the final push to claim the class honours came down to the finish of the last stage on the last rally of the year. One second! They had taken the class win and the championship.The first event this year for Craig Callander and son Ross would see them prepare Craig#s gravel spec Subaru Impreza at the last minute to take on their favourite event. The #Japanese Tractor# was a fair handful, a light steering alignment issue and a boost problem gave the pair some trouble although finishing th overall made up for the hassle. A fair result given Craig#s absence from tarmac for four years.Returning from the shed with his freshly painted Sunbeam was Alister Macarthur, this time with Claire Tilleyalongside. The freshly fettled #beam was looking and sounding good # crossing the finish th overall after two years out of the seat.Dochy and Ian were back out in the #blue bullet.# All was going well until they had a spin coming over a crest into a square left, losing the bumper and damaging the gear linkage. They managed to get the car back to the end of the Saturday afternoon leg to repair the gear linkage and almost stole the yellow bumper from the recce car until some legends appeared with the duo#s bumper in the back of their Land Rover. Back out onto the  mile #long one# on Saturday night and they had an issue # after a heavy landing over a crest the rear shocker bolt broke, making the car a handful to keep in a straight line. They had to finish another two stages before they could make it back to service, so a finish was all they wanted at this point # th overall and Dochys fourth finish in a row on Mull.Without doubt the driver to watch was Innes and his newly acquired co-driver Lewis Grfiths . The Mightywas spotted airborne at any chance, with the hydro can suspension screaming for a break at each service halt. It was almost all over as the nearside cv joint sheared and the car took a wild turn to the left # both Innes and Lewis thought they would end up IN the Belachroy pub. They managed to make it over the Lochs to the end of the final stage, claiming st overall.Eoghan was back out with Martin to settle the score from the DNF at the summer stages. Sadly a stage maximum time on stage two scuppered their chances of the overall result they were hoping for, however they did set some impressive times, clocking a th fastest time on the final stage.Jamie, back out for the final round of the STRC, was looking to continue his good run from the Pendragon and set a seventh fastest time on stage three in the extremely wet and tricky conditions. Trying to get his money#s worth from his entry fee Jamie, however, decided to take an extra couple of miles on the penultimate stage. Still, the C ran well all day and the conditions suited the car perfectly.Ian was back out with Greg and this time he was aiming to become the Scottish Tarmac Rally Champion for . They set off with five cars in the same class and they had to win the class to get Greg the honours. Setting the pace early they were leading throughout the event. Finishing the event first in their class and third overall meant the job was done # Greg claimed the championship win.The last event of the year saw Kirsty back in the co-drivers seat, gaining even more experience on her path to upgrading her licence. Some typical Knockhill weather was in store as Kirsty had her first taste of RWD rallying in the Mazda MX of Paul Sheard. Kirsty guided Paul around the very wet stages to claim th overall and some valuable points on the board for Paul#s Motorsport News Championship campaign.Special thanks to Alasdair MacConnell who has travelled many miles to don an orange bib and stand in the rain, wind and heat, all to show his support and play a vital part in any event. And to Gavin #Top Tog# Brown, who has been an avid rally man for years and continued to watch us all through the lens, capturing some of our most heroic moments. was a busy year, with a few of us still tinkering away in sheds.  will hopefully see theof Ally and Del Galbraith in their #new# MK Escort and Donald Bowness in the giant killing Nova making aafter some time out.PICS:Dougie Watt and Ian Parker flying in Finland before winning in Aberdeen Photo: Jii Pihlaja. no_a_RallyFinlandFather and son duo Craig and Ross Callendar came in th overall at this year#s Mull Rally. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_CraigCallanderEuan Thorburn took a drama filled Argyll Rally victory, adding to his  win on the event. title: bute meets ayrshire in memory of calum
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAn Argyll and Bute charity has joined forces with the Prince#s Foundation to offer families living with cancer short getaways at a five-star, self-catering cottage at Dumfries House estate, East Ayrshire.Caroline Speirs co-founded Calum#s Cabin with her husband Duncan and daughter Jenna to provide holiday homes on the Isle of Bute for children suffering from cancer or a cancer-related disease. Caroline and Duncan were parents to Calum, who sadly passed away aged  after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Knowing he and his family lived in a beautul part of the world, Calum wanted children suffering from cancer to come to Bute for special getaways where the entire family could cherish quality time together and recharge their batteries for what may lie ahead.The charity now runs several holiday homes on Bute and private flats in Glasgow for families travelling to the city for treatments at the Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Care and Royal Hospital for Children.Dumfries House Lodge is a -room, five-star country guest house with two self-catering cottages, all staffed round the clock.Eight families have been referred through the children#s charity so far to enjoy a four-night stay free of charge.Caroline said: #To allow Calum#s Cabin families to be helped in such a special way is an absolute honour. Our families have come away from each break with unforgettable memories and a renewed energy and focus for whatever may come next.#Louis MacCallum, director of commercial for the Prince#s Foundation at Dumfries House, said: #Anyone who has met Caroline and Duncan cannot fail to be inspired into helping their charity in any way they can. title: science matters the future for organ donation
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowPresently around , people in the UK are waiting for organ transplantation. All have end-stage organ failure, be it kidney, liver, lung or heart, and require a le-saving transplant.Organs for transplant usually come from bodies of people who agreed to donate before death. But as this does not produce enough organs, both Scotland and England plan to bring in an #opt out# system, meaning that on death a person#s agreement to organ donation is assumed unless they had actively opted out.Live donation is an alternative to awaiting a cadaveric organ. As people can live happily with one kidney or half a liver, family members or altruistic iniduals sometimes offer to donate these organs. Since matching donor and recipient tissue-type, however, is generally required these donations are not always acceptable.Now groups of tissue-type incompatible donor recipient pairs are getting together to mix and match, producing duos who are tissue-type-compatible. So let#s say Annie is rejected as a kidney donor for her sister Jean for incompatibility reasons, and similarly, Arthur is rejected as kidney donor for Jim. But pairing donor Annie with recipient Jim and Arthur with Jean could lead to two successful transplants. A recent report from the US describes the first ever bi-organ exchange involving a liver-kidney swap * .In this specic case a daughter wished to donate a kidney to her mother with renal failure but was rejected because she might later develop the same kidney problem. So she offered half of her liver in exchange for a kidney for her mother. Another donor was eventually identied who wanted to donate half her liver to her sister with liver failure but was rejected because her liver was too small. But she was cleared for kidney donation. So on the day of the swap four operations took place and two needy people received le-giving new organs.Although not presently being considered in the UK, with the ethical issues sorted, this multi-swap procedure opens the way for extended chains of donors and many more lives saved.*Torres et al Am J transplant. :-.
