Perhaps lost in the news of a budget increase at the Brandywell this week, was the revelation that Philip ODoherty will be at the club for the foreseeable future. The club Chairman has been the financial rock behind the club in recent years, and after revealing that he had increased Declan Devines budget by % earlier this week, his statement that he is going nowhere, despite his growing business responsibilities, was met with relief and delight amongst the fans, with one stating that ODoherty is the best signing that the club has ever made.ODoherty has business interests in Donegal, Dubai and America to name a few, but Derry City will always be at his heart. “I’m not going anywhere,” he said. “The only issue I have is that I travel probably about  per cent of my time but I’m here for the foreseeable future.“I’ve got three factories around the world and we’re looking at other locations around the world. But no matter where I am, I’m going to be there for Derry City.“Dodieis doing a great job running the office and Declan doesn’t need looking after. I don’t try to micro manage any of these guys, they all do their jobs.“We meet once every two or three weeks. Hecan email me or ring me anytime but in terms of face to face meetings, it’s about every two or three weeks.” googletag.cmd.push Delighted with progressODoherty brought Devine back to the club last season, and watched as the former goalkeeper, alongside his staff and a brand new playing squad, finished in fourth place, bringing European qualication and European money back to the club.I was absolutely delighted with last season, ODoherty continued. The way we ended the season before was demoralising to say the least.This manand the team he brought with him and the players he brought in did really well. They met all our expectations and more. I think were in a stronger place now but we still have a fair bit to go in terms of signings.Declans budget has been increased by  per cent on last year, he confirmed. We havent increased the ticket prices and were expecting a wee bit more sponsorship but not much more.Theres a fair amount of effort put in by the Board of Directors to basically to give Declan a bigger budget so he can compete at an even higher level than last year.Dundalk will be very hard to peg back, he added. All I can do is my bit and give hima bit more for his budget but still keep the club on a sound financial footing.Running the football club is a constant challenge for all involved, and ODoherty knows that will not change in . The Chairman though is determined to make his local club competitive.“It’s going to cost pound million to run the football club this year,” he stated. “That basically comes from contributions, sponsorship, gate receipts.“One of the disadvantages we have is we pay VAT on all our gate receipts, whether they’re season tickets or inidual match tickets. That’s a  per cent disadvantage on that part of our income. So we are hamstrung with that unlike other League of Ireland clubs because there’s no VAT on sporting events in the Republic.“Were making an effort in terms of increasing the budget and I do think we will challenge again this year.” googletag.cmd.push  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: Author spends decade visiting churches
story: A CO Down artist has written about a personal spiritual journey which took her to every church in Belfast.Bronagh Lawson spent ten years visiting hundreds of churches throughout the city, as well as some closer to home. The result is Belfast: City of Light, a new book in which she shares her experiences and asks some pertinent questions on matters of faith and beliefs.Bronagh began her journey as a non-churchgoer. Now, she says she is a dferent person.ldquoI did not set out to go on this journey or write this book, but simply started to follow an artistic thread like many artists over the centuries before me, she remarked. ldquoThe thread became so compelling and extraordinary that I eventually felt destined to write it down.Born in Newtownards in  to Frances and Paddy Lawson, who had ed to Belfast to oversee the design and building of the Ulster Museum, Bronagh spent her first two years on the Upper Newtownards Road in Belfast with her three older sisters, before moving to Portaferry in  and later to Strangford.Educated at Down High School, in  she attended art college in Bristol and then gained a first class degree in textiles fashion at Winchester School of Art, Hampshire. Moving to London on graduation, she won a Fulbright scholarship and attended Parsons School of Design in New York.Bronagh sometimes visited Northern Ireland and despaired. Prior to the end of the Troubles she spent time as a participant on ious cross-community development programmes before deciding to use her creativity in a dferent way.For  years she set up and ran cross-border, cross-community development programmes mostly within the enterprise sector in interfaceareas of Belfast. At the same time she explored her own upbringing during the Troubles and heard many stories from people in Belfast of experience she only saw on TV growing up and often switched off in horror.She spent three years based in North Belfast, between the republican New Lodge and loyalist Tigers Bay areas. Walking into work one day she collapsed. She had become incapable of processing the traumas that people living in some of most deprived areas of Europe were enduring on a daily basis.She found herself coming back to her original training as an artist and started a journey towards her own healing by going to church.Bronagh says she asked herself a lot of questions as she attended Protestant and Catholic services in Belfast and beyond.She says: ldquoWhatinstead of listening to the continuous repeated stories of Protestant vs Catholic in Belfast, an inidual had first-hand experience of visiting every church in the city for a service, simply looking and listening when going to each one ldquoWhat would they see and hear  As a non-church goer starting out on this journey, how would you feel ten years later  What is going on in churches in contemporary Belfast  How might this open-minded curiosity inform the continuous shting conversation about the city that I call home Belfast: City of Light costs pound and is available online at lulu. It is also available locally at Kevin Ogrsquos shop in Strangford..prettyPhoto

title: Bronagh loses over eight stone during incredible year
story: IF yoursquod love to slim down and feel better about yourself in , then please read about a young lady who made  an exceptional year.Bronagh OrsquoNeill lost eight stones and eight-and-a-half pounds in just  months with the help of Slimming World.Itrsquos crazy to think that this time last year Bronagh wasnrsquot even a Slimming World member. She had no idea the food optimising plan was so easy, nor did she realise how good she could feel from the inside out just by losing weight.Slimming World has five decades of experience helping millions of people to lose weight and also has a fun calendar of celebrations planned throughout the year.Bronagh says: ldquoWhile I was looking forward to Christmas  I knew it would be very dferent to the previous year.ldquoAfter making many changes in my lestyle in the last  months with food and exercise I knew Christmas was the time that would put me to the test.Bronagh says she is looking forward to new members joining her Slimming World group and seeing them discover that they can lose weight without feeling hungry or deprived.However,  is also going to be a special year for Bronagh. Shersquos getting married and because shersquos on target with her weight loss itrsquos going to be extra memorable.ldquoI love the principles of Slimming World and the promise of weight loss with no hunger, no judgment and freedom from guilt. Thatrsquos exactly what I needed to hear to get me started, she remarked.Slimming Worldrsquos food optimising eating plan is based foods that are best at satisfying your appetite and have the fewest calories per gramme.You learn how to make healthy choices, lose weight and keep the weight off without feeling hungry.Therersquos no such thing as a lsquoquick fixrsquo when it comes to losing weight and Slimming World has always offered sustainable, long-term weight loss, so itrsquos definitely the best choice for anyone wanting to get slim for le this January mdash and to have a great time in the process..prettyPhoto

title: Connaire chases Noel to finish line
story: THE fth race in the BornRun Forest series took place in Tollymore Forest Park on Saturday and almost  runners showed up to the event which offered both a k and a k route.Running conditions were perfect on the day and Tollymore provided the perfect location for this annual event which is now well-established as one of the must-do January races.Noel McNally, of Road Runners, was the first across the line in the k race, followed by Connaire McVeigh, of Newcastle AC and Brendan McIlhannon in third.The first female finisher in the k was Amy Bulman, of Willowfield Harriers. Karen Wilton, of Jog Lisburn, was runner-up and Chloe Gillard, of Fitness Factory, finished third.The K was won by junior runner Tom Crudgington, of Newcastle AC. David Conlfe, of PACE Running finished second and his clubmate Ricky McKnight came third.Junior athlete Lauren Madine, of East Down AC, came first in the female k race with her clubmate Anna Gardiner following two seconds behind to take the runner-up position. Dromorersquos Lily Rimmer came third.The next race in the award winning series takes place in Gosford Forest Parkon January . For more information or to enter go to www.bornrunevents.prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar pig farmer stars on UTV show
story: PIG farmer Robbie Neill is one of the new stars in the latest series of UTVrsquos Rare Breed mdash A Farming Year.The Crossgar man mdash who is also a full-time fireman in Belfast mdash shares his farming le raising pedigree Oxford Sandy pigs in the observational documentary series starting tomorrow night.Robbie will be making his first appearance in next Thursdayrsquos programme and is featured throughout half of the -episode series.He is seen being supported by his eldest son, Angus, whorsquos now aged nearly five, as well as his we, Louise, and -month-old daughter Connie.The arrival of Robbiersquos youngest child, eight-month-old James, is also featured in the programme, which follows hisprogress at Stonebridge Cottage Farm on the Derryboy Road over the last  months.The  year-old is delighted to be featured in the programme as he has only been rearing his rare breed of pigs for about three years.ldquoIf you had said to me over a year ago that I would be on Rare Breed, I would have laughed at you but here I am, said Robbie.ldquoI was very lucky that UTV approached me after a friend suggested me and itrsquos great to be featured in a show that we all love.While his brother Johnny still farms a beef herd at the familyrsquos nearby home farm, Robbie explained that he began to ersy into pig farming and decided that rearing rare breeds was the way he wanted to go.ldquoI wanted to rear a traditional, pedigree pig such as the Oxford Sandy which is a very good-looking pig, explained Robbie.ldquoI started off in a small way with a single litter and just grew it from there and over the last year, it has really started to take off.Robbie rears pigs for pork to be sold into local restaurants such as  The Georgian House in Comber and the Ispini Charcuterie based in Dungannon.However, he also sells whole pigs and half pig packages at his home farm shop which he runs with his we.Robbie has hit on a discerning market of people who are prepared to pay a little more for their meat when they know how the animal has been reared and processedHe says that itrsquos important to him to give his pigs the best diet and lethat he can in order to produce the best pork.ldquoI would say that the pigs have a better diet than me, joked Robbie, ldquoAnd itrsquos all local.Proving his commitment to his animalsrsquo welfare and using by-products of other local food and drink producers, Robbie feeds the pigs brewers grain from Farmaggedon Brewing in Comber, whey from a cheesemaker in Newtownards and fresh, locally produced vegetables.Robbie said: ldquoI like to call them eco-pigs as they are helping to use up other food and drink waste.He knows that there will be viewers who will fall in love with the pigs as the Oxford Sandy piglet is particularly cute.ldquoThe Oxford Sandy has orange-coloured patches and when therersquos a litter they can look like a bunch of little Dalmatian pups running around, he adds.Robbie says that while he and his family naturally get attached to some of the pigs, he can tell within a few weeks of birth, which ones will go on to slaughter and which will be kept for breeding.Filmed in all weathers, Rare Breed follows Robbie and nine other families from a iety of farms across Northern Ireland.The show features the producers of cattle, sheep, bees, llamas and this series, therersquos also a vet, and a contracting family who both play vital roles in the agri-food industry.The series is produced for UTV by local independent production company Crawford McCann Television. UTVrsquos Mark McFadden will narrate the series.Sponsored by Moy Park, Rare Breed ndash A Farming Year starts on Thursday at .pm on UTV.For further information on Robbiersquos produce, look for @stonebridgecottagefarm on Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Experienced Crossgar lift Mahon Cup in style
story: WITH multiple champions on show, including Crossgarrsquos recently-crowned All-Ireland winner, Kenny Campbell, the Mahon Billiards Cup final just before Christmas promised much and didnrsquot disappoint. First up was Christian Kirk from St Patrsquos against John Weston. Kirk started well with breaks of ,  and  to take an early -point lead.Weston gradually found his range and four  plus breaks of his own saw him take the lead at  points to Kirkrsquos .However, currently double Downpatrick inidual champion, Kirk responded superbly to hit a lovely  break, overtaking Weston before eventually winning out at  points to Westonrsquos battling .On the other table, Frankie Trainor was up against Colin Flanagan and was finding points hard to come by as Flanagan hit the ground running.A string of smallish breaks and a well-constructed , saw Flanagan race ahead, leading - and - as he eyed the winning line.Trainor, though, wasnrsquot finished and breaks of  followed by a gutsy  at the death, brought an air of respectability to the result as Flanagan won out at  points to .But for the late breaks by Kirk and Trainor, the match might have been over bar the shouting.As it was, after handicap adjustment, Crossgar were to take just a two point lead into the final tie between former Northern Ireland champion John McIntyre and Campbell.The Crossgar contingent were buoyed when Campbellrsquos first scoring visit to the table saw him make a  break.However, McIntrye wasnrsquot put off and breaks of  and  saw him lead by  on the board and  in the match overall.Campbell bagged another  break to re-take the lead, which was to change no less than seven times in the match.After a thrilling finale, further late breaks of  and  saw the younger Campbell break clear at the crucial time, as he closed out the match at  points to McIntyrersquos .League billiards correspondent Robert Pollock did the presentation honours, handing the Mahon Cup to Crossgar captain Weston.John thanked Drumaness for hosting the final in immaculate playing conditions, as usual and commiserated with the losing St Patrsquos boys before everyone enjoyed the usual post-match refreshments.Many thanks go to Seamus, Gary and Marty for their renowned hospitality.ST PATRICKrsquoS B CROSSGAR .prettyPhoto

title: Food bank donates over 250 parcels in Downpatrick
story: FOUNTAIN Food Bank in Downpatrick gave out  food parcels to local families in the run-up to Christmas.Volunteer co-ordinator Shirley Lennon said that while the food bank gave out  parcels for Christmas , this yearrsquos effort actually sustained more people during the season, feeding  people over two to three days.She said: ldquoIn one way itrsquos good to know that the parcels have been given out but it another way, its horric as that demand is still there.Mrs Lennon believes that demand for help has again increased on last year.ldquoAlthough we wonrsquot have the final numbers until the end of March, we have already given out  parcels to date this year, she explained.ldquoIn  , we gave out  parcels, in  , it was  parcels and this jumped to  parcels in  .ldquoWe believe that the increase is partly down to the fact that we are working more effectively in partnership with other statutory organiations who refer people to us and proactively ordered parcels for Christmas for families they are working with.ldquoWe also get referrals from organisations such as MACSand St Vincent De Paul and believe the fact that social workers are now working with GPs in Downpatrick in multidisciplinary teams is also helping to ensure that help is going to where it is needed most.Mrs Lennon said that some of the people who received parcels were in genuine need of a temporary helping hand.She said: ldquoWe helped one mother and her family as they were visiting and supporting a family member in hospital who has cancer. As the family has no car and survive on benefits, money was being used to pay for transport to the hospital.ldquoThen on another day, we were approached by a very distressed woman who literally had nothing at home as her marriage had just broken up. We were able to give her a parcel as well as signpost her to where she could get help for her mental health.Mrs Lennon added that the team of  volunteers were working flat-out in December to make up the parcels mdash with the help of three Ulster Rugby team players at one point.However, she added that the effort would not have been possible without the generosity of local donors.ldquoWe have had so much help this year and it ranges for local businesses giving us food stuff, people leaving in cash donations, people coming with bags of groceries and even one shopper who donated an entire trolley full of shopping from Asda, said Mrs Lennon.ldquoWe would like to thank each and every one of them for their generosity and continued support.Fountain Food Bank is run from Downpatrick Presbyterian Church Hall, Fountain Crescent in Downpatrick.For further information visit www.downpatrickpresbyterian.org foodbank..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 8%2C 1980
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash A plan to spruce-up Ballynahinch Square has been agreed between the Department of the Environment and the owners.It is expected to cost somewhere in the region of pound,, which will be shared equally between the Department and the Ker Estate, with Down Council acting as agents. It was confirmed this week that an offer of grant aid had been made by the Department and had been agreed in principle.The work will be done under an Environmental Improvement Spruce-Up Scheme and is aimed at giving the area a badly-needed facelt. Department officials are insisting that work begins before March , otherwise they will withdraw grant aid.ldquoTherersquos a limit to the money and itrsquos not an elaborate scheme, but wersquore hoping it will leave the centre of Ballynahinch in a more acceptable manner, a spokesman for the Department said.The whole square will be resurfaced and drained and a low wall is to be built all around, with vehicle and pedestrian access points.To coincide with the facelt, Department officials, in conjunction with the townrsquos Chamber of Trade, are appealing to owners of property in the square to carry out facelts to their own buildings.ldquoTherersquos not much point in brightening up the squarepeople do not take a civic pride, but perhapswe start the work others will he more amenable to doing something, the spokesman added.DOWNPATRICK mdash A pound, contract has been finalised this week for the building of new squash courts, with changing and recreational facilities, in Downpatrick.The new complex is an extension to existing facilities at the De La Salle schoolsrsquo campus where the sports club already enjoys the use of facilities for badminton and other indoor sports.Work is due to commence later this month by local firm Messrs Hugh J OrsquoBoyle Ltd, who have been awarded the contract, and it is hoped to have the project fully operational before Christmas this year.Announcing the details at a regular meeting of the La Salle Union Past Pupils Association, the president, Mr Michael Hamill, thanked the De La Salle community and the Department of Education for their financial support.He stated that the complex would be available to all members or the local community and hoped that this would encourage many past pupils of all the De La Salle schools to renew their association with the past pupilsrsquo union.BINS mdash Down Council clerk Mr Seamus Byrne has publicly apologised for the ldquomost inefficient bin collection service in the district during the past fortnight.Mr Byrne admitted this week that most areas in Down District are two days behind schedule, but he promised that every attempt was being made to bring the service up to date.He explained to a meeting of councillors that there had been number of problems with men of sick and with breakdowns in the councilrsquos fleet of lorries.One of the biggest problems, said Mr Byrne, was finding drivers for the lorries because a number of men had refused to do overtime. ldquoThe men are not obliged to do overtime and we cannot force them, he explained.Mr Byrne said all vehicles were on the road last weekend with the exception of one lorry in Downpatrick and he promised that all lorries would be in operation throughout this week.When quizzed by several councillors on a collection rota to clear the backlog, Mr Byrne stressed it would be nearly impossible to say what was going to happen in each area.ldquoI apologise for the most inefficient service, but every attempt is being made to put it in order, he added.FARMING mdash The total agricultural labour force in Co Down stands at , mdash the second highest in the province. The figure is contained in the agricultural census on the province, compiled by the Department of Agriculture and published this week.The total labour force is just  short of the labour force in Tyrone, the largest in the province. A breakdown of the total figure shows that the total workforce, excluding owners and their wives, is , in Co Down.The census also reveals there are , owners, partners and directors on Co Down farms and a breakdown of this figure shows that farming locally is still very much male dominated.Co Down farmers have traditionally required more seasonal or casual workers than where, with , being taken on in . Other figures contained in the report include , full-time family workers,  part-time family workers,  full-time hired workers and  part-time hired workers in Co Down.NEWCASTLE mdash The death has taken place in Cranborne, Victoria, Australia, of Father George Todd, formerly of Newcastle.Father Todd was ordained in All Hallows College, Dublin, in  and celebrated his first Mass in St Maryrsquos Church, Newcastle, on June  of that year.While he was awaiting his call to Australia he was appointed assistant curate in Castlewellan where the late Dean C McKenna was the PP.In  Fr Todd went to Australia and  years later he ed home on his first visit. He is survived by a sister and brother, who also reside in Australia.KILLINCHY mdash Former Killinchy man Norman McMordie has won the Young Farmersrsquo Clubs farm management competition.Norman, who received a travel bursary from the Northern Bank as his prize, is no stranger to success in farming circles. Last year he won two top awards and finished third in another major competition.Now , Norman will be able to put his skills to good use on his fatherrsquos farm at Ballygowan. His father is a well known breeder of pedigree polled Hereford and Simmental bulls and Norman helps out on the farm at weekends and on holidays.He moved to the Banbridge area due to work commitments as a sales development representative with Richardsonrsquos Fertilisers. Before that he was a member of Killinchy YFC.COMBER mdash A  year-old Comber girl, Libby Smyth, who is playing Fairy Lethargia in the current production of Mother Goose at the Arts Theatre in Befast, is really pulling in the pantomime fans.During rehearsals someone suggested Libby should try impersonating the Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher. She did and it has now become one for the most popular features of the show. Libbyrsquos updated and light-hearted Thatcherisms have the audience rolling in their seats.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh was the venue last night for a big training night for Scout leaders. The event in the Shore Street youth hall is one of a number organised for Scout leaders in Co Down this month.The training programme is being co-ordinated by Scout headquarters, with the new county commissioner, Mr Clive Scoular, doing much of the groundwork.Last night was the turn of the Beaver leaders, with the district commissioner, Mr Harry Galbraith, from Downpatrick, and the assistant county commissioner , Teresa Savage, introducing the activities.SAINTFIELD mdash Mr David Napier, of Belfast Road, Saintfield, has won pound in a competition organised by Dromona Butter. David, a schoolteacher at Bangor Grammar School, answered six questions relating to butter and supplied a slogan. He was presented with a pound cheque for his efforts.DRUMANESS mdash A flock of sheep were attacked by dogs at Crawfordstown Road, Drumaness, last Thursday in the latest sheep worrying outbreak to hit the area. Six sheep were worried, but fortunately only one was seriously injured.KILKEEL mdash A Kilkeel man who has been honorary secretary of the townrsquos branch of the Royal National Leboat Institution for  years is to be rewarded with a gold badge for devoted service.Mr Cecil Baxter is to receive the badge, there highest the RNLI can offer, at the annual presentation of RNLI awards in the Royal Festival Hall, London, in May..prettyPhoto

title: Inspirational Seaforde woman to take on seventh marathon
story: A SEAFORDE woman is getting ready to run her seventh marathon after recovering from cancer.Pat Shields is an inspiration to those of us who have already broken our New Year resolutions.In her darkest moments of , while she was undergoing a series of chemotherapy treatments to fight a cancer diagnosis, Pat recalls feeling at a low ebb.ldquoIt was bleak but I found something deep within me to keep going, she said. ldquoPeople who undergo treatment for cancer need to know there is light at the end of that very dark tunnel. They need to keep fighting because everything you think you have lost will all come back again.ldquoIt can be a time when you donrsquot look great, your confidence is low and even your memory begins to fade. People must realise it is not the end of the world.Before she discovered a cyst on her breast, Pat had already completed four marathons having recaptured the joy of running she knew as a young girl growing up around the fields of Ballynagross, outside Downpatrick.Pat said: ldquoI used to take off and run for miles, setting my own routes across the fields and making the most of the fresh air, but I put it all aside when my children came along.It was only when she reached her late s that the opportunity arose for her to take up running again.She said: ldquoMurlough Athletics Club in Dundrum were holding a recruitment drive at the time. The club was offering a six-week programme for beginners, three times a week.Pat soon rediscovered the running bug that had lay dormant for years. She said: ldquoWe gradually built up three miles at a time. When I joined Murlough AC, it had around  members and it has grown to become one of the biggest clubs in Northern Ireland, with  members.Pat describes her fellow runners as ldquolovely honest people, who are always there for her. She said: ldquoThey have certainly helped tremendously with my recovery. They are non-judgemental and share a great deal of their own lives with you. Wersquore like a family in away.Pat believes it was having a reasonable level of fitness that helped her to recover from the devastating diagnosis. She said: ldquoI was at my fittest. I was running marathons. I just couldnrsquot take it in.ldquoIt was crushing news, she said. ldquoUp until that point I felt younger and fitter than I had in ages. The word cancer certainly stops you in your tracks.In spite of the darkness, Pat felt encouraged to get well and dreamed of crossing another finish line.Pat is currently training for her seventh marathon run which is taking place in Paris this April.Running has taken Pat to many cities in the world, including London and Dublin, but she says nothing compares to the beauty and charm of running the Mourne Way ndashthe off road run that traverses the foothills of the Mourne Mountains from Newcastle to Rostrevor.Pat says that before her illness she would give up too easily. Now she gives up on nothing.ldquoRunning is part of my le now, she remarked. ldquoOne of the many upsides is I never have to watch what I eat. No one can say they are never too old to run. I refer to my setback as just a blip in a chapter of my le.She adds: ldquoI would encourage people just to get back up and rediscover the good things in le. Do rest, but never believe that itrsquos over.ldquoMaybe one day trouble may knock on my door again but when it does Irsquoll just have to get up and get on with it again..prettyPhoto

title: Lauren takes major 5k title
story: AT the fth race in the BornRun series at Tollymore Forest Park over the weekend the sun shone and the mood was good.The k race left the car park area and headed down towards the main Tollymore entrance then turned up to the right taking the runners down gravel forest trails for most of the first k.As to be expected in a forest park, there were then a few uphills followed by flatter parts and then one more incline coming up to the last k. After that it was straight towards the finish line on good ground allowing for fast finishes.Lauren Madine maintained her winning streak in this series, with a spirited run, holding on to first place in . with Anna Gardiner, second female, a mere second behind.Lily Rimmer, of Dromore, completed the ladiesrsquo podium in ..Sharon Madine demonstrated that she hasnrsquot been slacking over the holiday either, coming fourth female in a respectable .. Another good day out for the EDAC trio.The rest of the club must have been in recovery mdash either from the exploits of the Cracker the week before or simply the aftermath of the festivities as no one  turned out to race over the weekend.There were, however, a few notable performances in parkruns with Mackenzie Murray claiming the title of first finishing male in Castlewellan for the first time.He finished in  minutes dead, slightly disappointed not to break that barrier, but the sub  is surely in the offing.Oliver Robinson got the year off to a good start by breaching the  minute barrier on New Yearrsquos Day and then further whittling his time to . on Saturday past, so plenty for him to aim for. Suzy Smith has also managed to PB on her first two runs at Castlewellan in January. At Victoria Park on Saturday Aaron McGrady was the first finisher in ..Loose endsOn New Yearrsquos Day Paddy McDonald was the sole representative in the annual Race Across the Glens, in Glenarf Forest Park, which used to be on my lsquonot to be missed listrsquo and he did well to complete the gruelling route in under the hour, clocking .. Well done Paddy.Also taking advantage of her Christmas visit to the locality was Hannah Somani, who was here to participate in the Cracker race, as she finally took possession of her Podium  Sport voucher prize, resulting from her efforts in the Seeley Cup race at the end of November, in which she was the third scoring member of the East Down AC female team which took second place overall.Coming upThe calendar for the next few weeks offers plenty of cross country for juniors and seniors alike.This weekend is the Mathieson Cup and Shield at Mallusk on Sunday with entries on the day. Details can be found at https:athleticsni.org Fixtures Mathieson-Cup-and-Shield- while on Sunday, January , round four of this yearrsquos McGradyrsquos Financial Services Junior Cross Country takes place in Delamont Country Park beginning at pm.Jimmyrsquos TenItrsquos hard to believe that wersquore talking about Jimmyrsquos Ten again, how time flies. Bt the online entry facility is already open at www.athleticsni.org and entries are flooding in.This is your opportunity to take advantage of the attractive early bird entry rates which will be applicable until January . Not only that, but it will ensure your entry for what is regarded as one of the top k road races in the calendar.k early bird until January , costs poundpoundmdash thereafter pound  until close on Friday, March , or the cap of  is reached.k relayearly bird until January , pound, thereafter pound until close on Friday March, , or the cap of  teams is reached.So, donrsquot say you havenrsquot been warned. Best wishes to all local runners for the coming season and indeed throughout the year..prettyPhoto

title: M%26S ‘interested’ in Lidl Newcastle base
story: A NUMBER of leading retailers, including Marks and Spencer, are reportedly interested in investing in Newcastle.In papers submitted ahead of todayrsquos planning meeting, it is claimed thatLidl secures planning permission for its new store, it will seek permission to sub-let its current base at Railway Street to another retailer.Commercial property consultants CBRE mdash who act on behalf of Lidl mdash say it has undertaken an initial exercise to test the market for potential replacement occupiers of the current Railway Street site.CBRE says that within Newcastle town centre, it is aware of several brands who have what is described as an active requirement for the area.The commercial property consultants said MS Simply Food, Home Bargains and BM Bargain have expressed an initial interest in Lidl leaving Railway Street.ldquoIt would appear reasonable to assume that a replacement occupier could be secured for this property, CBErsquos submission continues. ldquoNone of these retailers are currently represented in Newcastle..prettyPhoto

title: Magpies in final flight
story: MAGNIFICENT Cill Chua are through to the All-Ireland Club SFC final for the first time.The Magpies overcame red hot favourites St Endarsquos Ballyboden - to - at Kingspan Breffni on Saturday and they will now face defending champions Corofin at Croke Park on Sunday, January .Goals from Ryan Johnston and Daryl Branagan proved crucial in cancelling out an eight-point haul from Ballybodenrsquos Basquel brothers in a thrilling encounter that went to the wire.Cill Chua manager Mickey Moran changed things around for this clash and yet again his tactics proved spot-on as the Dublin kingpins were unable to break free from their shackles.The amazing odyssey for the East Down side continues all the way to the biggest day in the club calendar against perhaps the greatest side in the history of club football mdash a fact that is not lost on team selector Conleth Gilligan.ldquoTherersquos a great buzz around Cill Chua at the moment and in the wider Down area in general, he said after Saturdayrsquos match.ldquoDown football has been a wee bit stagnant this last while. That will give everybody a lt going into the New Year.Gilligan described Corofin as an ldquoncredible team.He went on: ldquoFor a club team to go with that level of consistency, we know the challenge thatrsquos there. From that perspective, wersquore there.ldquoWersquore going to savour this good feeling and wersquoll be back down to earth tomorrow with a bang knowing wersquore playing one of the best club teams that probably ever played the game.Cill Chua have certainly flourished with the underdogrsquos mantle, but Gilligan is not unduly worried by that tag.ldquoIt is not something we pay much attention to, he revealed. ldquoWe went to a lot of games ndash even the county final in Down mdash with people tipping against us, so it isnrsquot unusual. Itrsquos not something thatrsquos ever talked about, but players are players and they want to put two fingers up to the critics and Kilcoo are no dferent, he admitted.Gilligand, who is manager Moranrsquos right hand man, is confident his side will acquit themselves well at Croke Park against Corofin.ldquoA team that is going for three All-Irelands, itrsquos phenomenal and wersquoll just have to prepare as best we can and give the best account of ourselves, he said.ldquoGetting to Croke Park is the pinnacle for every player. Some of these boys have been soldiering for - years.ldquoThis is just reward for a lot of hard graft. Itrsquos where we want to be and now our whole focus will be on trying to become the All-Ireland club champions.ldquoObviously, itrsquos a great thrill to be looking forward to playing at Croke Park. It will be a very special occasion for the club, but itrsquos a massive test at the same time.ldquoThis club has shown tremendous determination over a number of years and now they will bid to do themselves justice on the biggest stage..prettyPhoto

title: Margaret shines in first House of Lords speech
story: BARONESS Margaret Ritchie delivered her maiden speech in the House of Lords late yesterday afternoon.The former South Down SDLP MP mdash who formally took her place in the Lords in early November mdash sits on the Labour benches and is delighted with the opportunity she has been given to re-engage with mainstream politics.Elected as a member of the former Down Council in , Miss Ritchie went on to become an MLA, Stormont Social Development Minister, SDLP leader and MP, with her appointment to the House of Lord opening a signicant new chapter for her.In her opening Lords address, Miss Ritchie gave members and overview of her political career, explaining that her title Baroness Ritchie of Downpatrick reflected not only her birth origins, but also political philosophy of inclusion.She said she ldquofirmly believes in St Patrick and his unying message, explaining that the patron saint was a fth century Christian pluralist who belonged to everybody.ldquoI believe that we have to transcend political, ethnic and religious dferences to compromise and to bring that measure of healing which is urgently required in the fractious world today, said the Baroness, explaining that St Patrick began and ended his Christian ministry in the environs of Downpatrick.ldquoI am a democratic Irish Nationalist of the social democratic tradition and a firm believer in pluralism, inclusion and building reconciliation. I am guided by the principles of the Good Friday Agreement.Baroness Ritchie also recalled the words of the very early th century Irish political thinker, AE Russell, who said: ldquoThe strength of Irish culture lies, I believe, in plurality rather than unormity.The view that national culture is a guarantor of homogeneous identity is no longer tenable. A living culture follows a multiplicity of voices. Authentic culture is not a matter of ourselves alone. Baroness Ritchie said that running alongside the Good Friday Agreement, Russellrsquos words are the embodiment of her political philosophy mdash partnership, working together, respect for political and ethnic dference and unity in ersity.She then focused on the Queenrsquos speech, issuing a reminder that it dealt with a plethora of issues, with Brexit, the environment, National Health Service, climate change and devolved Institutions chief among them.ldquoOf these, Brexit has been one of the greatest political catalysts in Britain and Ireland, said Baroness Ritchie.ldquoIt has consumed all aspects of our lives in Northern Ireland since the referendum of June  where the people voted to remain in the EU. It has impacted on identity, sovereignty and nationality.ldquoLike the majority in Northern Ireland I want to remain in the EU and realise that due to the Governmentrsquos majority in this parliament we will leave the one institution that has provided so much political, social and economic stability on the island of lreland.Baroness Ritchie argued that EU membership had diluted territorial and mind borders and contributed much to reconciliation and developing the economy and infrastructure, urging the British government to look at how this can be achieved in any new working arrangements.ldquoBrexit has undermined the principles of the Good Friday Agreement in relation to reconciliation and building a shared society, the maiden speech continued.ldquoIt has deepened political isions at a time when our political institutions were collapsed. Being a concept that is essentially about the economy it has become a major constitutional issue in Northern Ireland.ldquoMoreover, the EU Withdrawal Bill, which will give effect to Brexit, will have direct consequences for trade between Britain and Ireland and between Northern Ireland and Britain. It will also reduce parliamentary accountability and lessen protections for workersrsquo rights.Baroness Ritchie said people do not want borders either in Ireland or in the Irish Sea. She insisted they want to build reconciliation, intra community political progress, economic and social regeneration and social justice,the very factors she explained that were enhanced by EU membership and which could be damaged when the UK leaves.She continued: ldquoWe need the closest possible links with the EU. We need favourable trading terms with the EU and as a cautionary warning to the government, there canrsquot be zero trade details with the EU and then do our own thing. Borders and bureaucracy need to be lessened and a comprehensive trade agreement with the EU is required.ldquoThere is a need for access to the biggest market in Britain which takes half of our agricultural food sales from Northern Ireland which is equivalent of pound.bn. Coming from an area where there are two fishing ports, the fishing industry is looking for the current unhindered and unfettered access to itrsquos main market in Britain to continue. I support that concept too.On the wider political issue, Baroness Ritchie said devolved institutions need to be up and running in Northern Ireland, expressing hope that the current Stormont talks process will bear fruit for the local population.ldquoThat is what the population is yearning for and what I hope can be achieved to help achieve a healing process and a period of moderation.Turning to the weeks and months ahead, Baroness Ritchie said she hopes that during her time in the House of Lords mdash along with other Lords and Baronesses mdash she wants to work towards building reconciliation, fairness, equality and a shared society in Northern Ireland, explaining that this requires a plan to ldquoend ision and bring down the physical and mental walls of ision.She declared: ldquoI would hope that we can work across this House to achieve that process of moderation and peaceful politics in Northern Ireland a comprehensive trade deal with the EU to assist our economy and a plan to end austerity and poverty and ensure proper financial mitigations are in place to deal with the punitive rigours of welfare reform.ldquoClimate change needs to be tackled, just look at the floods in Britain and the intensity of the heat in Australia which has resulted in the bush fires, and whilst reference is made to tackling it in the Queenrsquos Speech, this issue needs international efforts. I believe continued membership of the EU is required to address and offset manrsquos inhumanity to our precious planet.Baroness Ritchie concluded her speech by highlighting how much she is looking forward to working with colleagues across the House on a range of policy issues over the coming months and years..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting called to address Saintfield sewage issues
story: THE current ban on new development in Saintfield will be discussed at the end of the month when local politicians meet with senior officials from NI Water.The temporary ban was imposed by the organisation in July  after it confirmed that it was not permitting new connections to the townrsquos sewer system.With Saintfieldrsquos sewage treatment plant approaching the end of its capacity, NI Water is in the process of completing a comprehensive drainage area planning model for the town, with the exercise also focusing on the treatment plant which continues to comply with all stringent environmental discharge standards.The detailed study was ordered in the wake of a number of sewage spills at the Old Grand Jury Road in the town during periods of heavy rain.NI Water engineers have installed special valves along sections of the sewer network at this part of the town in a bid to prevent future spills but have confirmed that no additional work is planned until the drainage area study has been completed. This means that the temporary ban is set to remain in place.At Monday nightrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, politicians discussed the detail of a letter from NI Water which detailed that the organisation has identied a requirement in the region of around pound.bn to maintain safe, clean drinking water and address main issues with sewer networks between  and .The news comes after NI Water revealed recently that during this period, an additional poundm investment will be required across the council area.While politicians are concerned about the poor waste water infrastructure in ious parts of the district, the need for investment in Saintfield is viewed as a key priority by many concerned atthe current moratorium on new-build schemes.The lack of investment in the districtrsquos sewerage infrastructure is being blamed on years of underinvestment in the system and the failure to upgrade networks of pipes installed decades ago which are struggling to cope with demand.Rowallane councillors Terry Andrews and Billy Walker say the situation in Saintfield needs to be addressed as a matter or urgency.Cllr Andrews described the detail of the NI Water letter as ldquoparticularly worrying and said the scale of the investment is unlikely to be made available by the government.ldquoThe current housing ban and the need to upgrade Saintfieldrsquos sewerage network is impacting on a signicant number of people and has ramications for the construction industry and buildersrsquo suppliers, he added.Cllr Walker said there were ldquoserious issues in Saintfield with the moratorium on new-build having an impact. He said the sewerage network needs an upgrade and this must be carried out as soon as possible.ldquoIn the past, raw sewage has been back flowing into peoplersquos toilets and spewing out from underneath manhole covers into gardens. Such a situation is intolerable. The current system cannot cope.Cllr Walker said the problem was not with the townrsquos sewage treatment plant but the pipes which supply it, explaining that suggested level of investment required to tackle the problem is in the region of poundm.He added: ldquoPeoplersquos lives in Saintfield are being made a misery. In the first instance, the poundm needed for the town must be found. If we donrsquot get satisfaction from NI Water at the end of the month and the Assembly is not sitting, we need to go directly to a direct rule minister.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke said NI Water was making it clear that it did not have the budget to carry out the required work and blamed austerity measures on cuts to public services.ldquoI hope the Assembly will be up and running and we have a local minister in place and that there will be the required cash injection. The ban on new development does have an impact, particularly on the construction industry. The reduction on the block grant also isnrsquot helping.Independent councillor Jarlath Tinnelly said no big decisions were ever taken locally, but ldquokicked down the road forever and a day because political parties are afraid to make them.He added: ldquoThere is a day of reckoning coming for all public services and I remember reading years ago that the introduction of water charges would sort out the infrastructure problem.ldquoI am certainly not advocating that course, but the point is that these big decisions are pushed further along for someone  to deal with. Now there is nowhere  to go..prettyPhoto

title: Modest price rises ‘boost’ to help first time house buyers
story: A DOWNPATRICK estate agent has welcomed a leading mortgage providerrsquos findings that claimed house prices in the Newry, Mourne and Down area remain the ldquomost modest in the UK.John Thompson from Ulster Property Sales says the report from the Halax is good news for first time buyers.He said the report, which states that house prices locally have seen the smallest percentage increase in the UK over the last  years, bodes well for the local housing market.Mr Thompson, a veteran of the industry ndash with  yearsrsquo experience of selling homes, said: ldquoHouse prices remain affordable in Newry Mourne and Down and this is great news.He explained: ldquoPrices are driven by a buoyant rental market which in turn underpins the buyers market. With interest rates being relatively low, young couples see that a monthrsquos rent could afford them a monthly mortgage repayment.According to the Halax report,  years ago the average house in Newry Mourne and Down cost pound,. In  the average price increased by % to pound,, putting the area firmly at the bottom of the UK table.Over the same period the average house price in the UK increased by %, with Northern Ireland seeing a % increase over the same period.However, Mr Thompson described the housing market as ldquodelicately balanced and did not like uncertainty.He said: ldquoIn recent years we have seen a dramatic growth in the rise of temporary positions across a number of professions, including banking and teaching.ldquoWhile they are well paid positions, it means these young people are unable to attain a mortgage.Despite this, Mr Thompson says he has been seeing a growth in first time buyers lately.He said: ldquoPrices are still reasonably affordable and are in line with wages ndash this is what we estate agents call lsquoan appropriate multiplersquo.ldquoSo the cost of a mortgage still remains very competitive. I recall a period in the mid s when interest rates reached % which caused much uncertainty in the market.ldquoWe also have great schools across Co Down and this is attracting young couples from England to relocate here.Mr Thompson said one area of concern was the impact Brexit may have on the property market.He remarked: ldquoThe elephant in the market now is Brexit and it has caused the pause button to be pushed. We are still waiting as to what the up side and the down side will be.ldquoWe will soon have some clarity with the Brexit deadline on January  and this should help to stabilise the situation..prettyPhoto

title: Objectors to discuss Lidl store application
story: A PLANNERSrsquo recommendation to approve a new poundm Lidl store in Newcastle will be discussed by local politicians at a meeting in Newry this morning.The supermarket giant is seeking permission for the new store at the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site in the town.The development proposal also includes a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team at the . acre Shanslieve Drive site in the resort.Entrance to the proposed store will be via Bryansford Road, with the plannersrsquo approval recommendation due to be discussed at this morningrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site were originally submitted in January  with permission being sought to bulldoze the existing school to pave the way for the construction of a new food store and the dedicated centre for the volunteers who run the mountain rescue team. Lidl claims its proposal will create an additional  jobs.In late November, the local council confirmed that outline permission granted in March for the multi-million pound development was to be quashed as a result of a judicial review brought by developer Don Holdings Ltd.However, days later the agenda for the December meeting of the Planning Committee included a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve the new store proposal. The recommendation was subsequently withdrawn, but features on the agenda for todayrsquos meeting with a recommendation to approve.Permission has also been granted to a number of people to address todayrsquos Planning Committee meeting.Due to address councillors are planning consultant, Andy Stephens, who is objecting to the proposal, while Seamus McMullan Architects have requested to address politicians on behalf of Dr M Rooney who is also opposed to the Lidl proposal.Further speaking rights requests have been received from Conleth Rooney BL on behalf of Don Holdings Ltd, objecting to the application, with Lidlrsquos Norther Ireland Regional Director Conor Boyle and Nicholas McCrickard from the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team, also due to address committee members.The development proposal includes plans for almost  parking spaces, eight of which are reserved for mountain rescue team members.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal, with planners receiving  objections. Five letters in support of the new rescue team base proposal have also been lodged.In papers submitted ahead of todayrsquos meeting, planners reaffirm that none of the statutory consultees including the Department for Infrastructure, Rivers Agency, Environment Agency and the local environmental health department, have lodged any objections to the redevelopment of the former school site.Lidl has consistently argued that its current base at Railway Street in Newcastle is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.The store argues the Railway Street base was only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found. Lidl says it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the Shanslieve Drive site became available, with the planned mountain rescue team centre providing the volunteers with a permanent base.Lidl said a large number of reports have been submitted with the planning application which confirm that the proposal will have no ldquoadverse effects on the environment or amenity of local residents.In addition, the supermarket giant says its development plan will regenerate a brownfield site with ldquomodern, attractive buildings and has signicant economic benefits.Objectors to the new store proposal claim that there are ldquoserious errors in the transport assessment submitted in conjunction with the application, inaccurate land ownership information, unachievable visibility spays and out-of-season traffic surveys.In addition, it will be argued today that in determining the planning application and making a recommendation to councillors, the local authority has done so without a thorough assessment having been undertaken and without being furnished with all the necessary information required to support a robust decision that the ldquoproposal to build on any particular site is acceptable, in principle..prettyPhoto

title: Plea for opt in organ donation discussions
story: LOCAL politicians are to examine how they can promote the importance of organ donation.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is working with the South Eastern and Southern health trusts on the issue, with many councillors keen to see plans for an opt out system.This means that people would agree to donate their organs with those who do not wish to do this signing a register. However, this does not currently exist.At Monday nightrsquos monthly meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council, a letter from the Permanent Secretary at the Department of Health confirmed that there are no plans in place at present to introduce so-called opt out legislation.However, Mr Richard Pengelly said that work is continuing to achieve higher rates of donation and transplantation to ensure that more people are able to receive the gt of an organ.It is estimated that someone dies every six weeks in Northern Ireland waiting for an organ donation.At Monday nightrsquos council meeting, Rowallane councillor Kathryn Owen said she was not surprised at the content of Mr Pengelleyrsquos letter, explaining that there is not much he can do without the required legislation being in place.ldquoIs there anything we can do at council level  she asked.ldquoA lot of the things we would hear on this issue from people is that it is something they have never really thought about or spoken to their family about. For others it is something grim and morbid and an issue that they do not want to talk about.Cllr Owen said there were people dying in traffic accidents that would be perfectly good donors, but their family members do not know whether they wanted to donate or not.ldquoThere are literally people dying and perfectly good organs going into the ground. Is there anything that we can do to educate people and push a bit more on this issue as far as people putting themselves on the donor register  she asked.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew said organ donation was an issue she highlighted during her year as the districtrsquos first citizen, explaining that workshops were held involving a number of young people who spoke with representatives from the ldquoBraveheart organisation.She described the event as ldquohugely successful and suggested the organ donation issue could be one for discussions across the districtrsquos DEAs.Cllr Mulgrew added: ldquoOrgan donation is a conversation families hope that they do not have to have. There is an appetite for information on this issue.Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews also backed the suggestion for the organ donation issue to be discussed at DEA level and said it should also be discussed with the Education Authority and local health trusts.Council director Michael Lipsett confirmed that he will be bringing a report on the organ donation issue to a future meeting of the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee.He said the report will focus on how the council is going to approach the issue and will contain information on its work with the Public Health Authority, local health trusts and Education Authority..prettyPhoto

title: PSNI helicopter used in search after attempted burglaries at weekend
story: POLICE have been praised for their swt response to an incident in Killyleagh last Sunday after reports of attempted break-ins at homes in the town.A helicopter was deployed as part of a major operation which subsequently resulted in the arrest of a  year-old man near Killinchy.Connor Martin Haughey, of Forest Street, Belfast, appeared in court in Newtownards yesterday charged with a series of offences including burglary, taking and damaging a vehicle, no insurance and possessing as an article with a blade or point in a public place.The case was adjourned, with Haughey remanded in custody until January  when he is due to appear at Downpatrick Court.The ious charges he faces are in connection with burglaries in the Saintfield and Killinchy areas. It is understood he was arrested after police received a number of reports of suspicious activity in the Ringhaddy area, near Killinchy.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker has praised police for their swt response to the incident and has urged people to review their home security and ensure that their front and rear doors are locked at all times.He said a suspicious car in the Grove and Kerry estates sparked alarm last Sunday with residents calling for the police who responded swtly, deploying a number of officers, including aerial support via the PSNI helicopter.ldquoI would appeal to people to ensure that their doors are locked at all times, said Cllr Walker.ldquoI would also encourage people across the district to check in with their elderly neighbours and remind them to never open their doors to strangers.ldquoPolice were swtly on the scene in Killyleagh last Sunday which was very reassuring for residents who very much appreciated the quick response, he continued.The Rowallane politician also encouraged elderly residents in particular not to open their doors to strangers.He said residents concerned about people calling at their homes should always be asked to show their ID accreditation for the organisation they claim to represent.ldquoVirtually all staff from ious organisations now carry ID cards which feature a photograph of the person carrying it. The card also includes details such as their name and, in some cases, a unique serial number.ldquoHomeowners worried about callers to their homes should also attach a chain to the inside of their front door and always ask callers to hold up their ID card to a window or put it through the letterbox so it can be checked, without having to open the door.Cllr Walker encouraged all residents to never be afraid to check a callerrsquos ID..prettyPhoto

title: Roadworks resume to extend natural gas network
story: WORK continues this week on the multi-million pound scheme to expand Northern Irelandrsquos natural gas network to East Down.Phoenix Natural Gas has been working across the district for the past two years with contractors recommencing work on Monday to lay a new mains pipe in Downpatrick, the districtrsquos largest town.Work is also due to start at Lynn Doyle Place in the town and at Mill Hill in Castlewellan and Todds Hill in Saintfield as part of a district-wide poundm investment which aims to provide , customers with access to mains gas.Work on the Downpatrick scheme represents a poundm investment by the company in the town which is also linking Ballynahinch, Castlewellan, Dundrum, Newcastle, Saintfield and Spa to the natural gas network.As the largest town in the extension project, Downpatrick is set to benefit from a multi-million pound investment to improve the townrsquos infrastructure and deliver the many benefits of natural gas to the area.On Monday contractors started work to provide a new mains pipe at the Ballyhornan Road, between the Knocknashinna and Ardglass road junctions.When this has been completed, contractors plan to move to nearby Edward Street where work is scheduled to last for one week.Over the coming weeks, a new mains pipe will be laid at Racecourse Hill, between the Killough Road and Stream Street junctions, with the work scheduled to last for two and a half weeks.A new mains gas pipe will also be laid at the Flying Horse Road on the outskirts of the town, between the Ardglass and Killough road junctions. Work in the area is expected to take around four weeks to complete.Phoenix says while it understands that its planned programme of work will cause some disruption, it will take all relevant measures to mitigate this. In addition, the company says it is pleased that the interest levels from homeowners in Downpatrick wishing to connect to the gas network have been consistently strong.In a letter to local politicians, Phoenix says that it continues to receive regular queries from householders that donrsquot currently have access to the mains network, encouraging the company to make gas available as quickly as possible.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran has asked residents and commuters in the town to remain patient as work on the multi-million pound scheme continues to provide householders and businesses access to a new form of energy.ldquoPhoenix has written to residents who are most likely to be affected by the next phase of pipe-laying to ensure that they are fully aware of what is being proposed, he continued.ldquoThe company recognises that its investment does result in disruption but is quick to resolve issues when they arise. The poundm investment across East Down to deliver natural gas is very signicant.Cllr Curran also praised Phoenix for its engagement with residents and the business community as it rolls out its pipe-laying programme across the county town in particular.The Downpatrick councillor has also confirmed that he plans to contact Phoenix officials to discuss the potential for weekend working as part of the drive to keep disruption to a minimum.Cllr Curran said while the arrival of natural gas has been welcomed in many quarters, Phoenix faces the unenviable task of delivering a y construction scheme while keeping residents and business owners reasonably happy.He added: ldquoThe company has done its very best to date and there is no doubt that delivering the natural gas network is challenging. It is also not without its dficulties at times due to ious factors outside the companyrsquos control.ldquoAs work continues this week and over the months ahead, it is important that people remain patient and understanding as contractors get on with the job of providing consumers with increased choice when it comes to selecting their energy provider..prettyPhoto

title: Twelfth child for Saintfield couple
story: MEET the Donoghues mdash now officially the largest family in Northern Ireland.The Saintfield family entered the record books when baby daughter Molly mdash their th child mdash arrived on New Yearrsquos Day.Molly, who weighed lb oz, was born at the Ulster Hospital shortly after  noon last Wednesday.Dad Johnand mum Tessa , were thrilled to introduce little Molly to her  siblings ndash six brothers and five sisters mdash who waited excitedly to welcome her home.Saying good night in the Donoghue household sounds more like a classroom roll call. Eldest daughter Tessa is  and a great help to her mum. Then there is Bobby , John , Savannah , Joseph , Sinead , Shannon , Ronnie , Reggie, , Tommy , Clariceand now little Molly.Tessa says she canrsquot wait to hear the cry of each newborn baby and hold it in her arms.Tessa, who, surprisingly, is an only child, said: ldquoMolly is already a great wee sleeper and her six brothersand five sisters are really excited to have someone  to play with.ldquoEveryone who meets the children always comments on how well behaved they all are. They go to St Colmcillersquos Primary School in Downpatrick where we all lived until recently when we needed to find a bigger house.ldquoMolly was born by normal delivery. In fact, all of my children were born naturally except for John. He was over lbs when he was born and was delivered by caesarean section. It is a great blessing to have every one of them born healthy and well.Tessa laughs at the idea of having as much experience in childbirth as some midwives. She said: ldquoThe midwives donrsquot give me advice and tips any more. They are quite content that I know what Irsquom doing at this stage. None of my babies wake in the middle of the night for a feed. They are usually very good.Tessa says she could not cope without the help of John, who she describes as a ldquogreat father and ldquovery supportive.John and Tessa have known each other for almost all of their adult lives.Tessa said: ldquoWe went together for a short time when we were very young, but then went our separate ways. Then one day a few years later I came upon a number written down with no name above it. I was very curious as to who the number belonged to and so I rang it.Unbeknown to Tessa, who lived in Kent at the time, John had decided to buy a new SIM card for his mobile phone. Just as he plugged it in and set it down to charge, Tessa rang mdash and the rest is history.The Donoghues go through  nappies a week, have a weekly shopping bill of over pound and are undeterred by an uncertain economy. John says ldquohis children are his wealth and it appears the Donoghues are not on their own.ldquoItrsquos been said that money canrsquot buy love, says John, who gave up his job to become a hands-on dad. ldquoWhile our  children have soaked up any extra income for fancy cars or Mediterranean holidays, we wouldnrsquot have it any other way.ldquoDisposable income or not, le with a big family is a blast and with so much love to contend with, I consider myself a rich man.Waving the Recorder team off after their family photo shoot, Tessa joked: ldquoWersquoll see you back here again next year with child number ..prettyPhoto

title: Walker braves the shave for Sophie’s fundraiser
story: A LOCAL politician is having his head shaved next month to help a Ballynahinch schoolgirlrsquos fundraising initiative on behalf of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker will have his locks shaved off by  year-old Sophie Mills, who is a student at Ballynahinch High School.Sophie has been diagnosed with Albinism and is on the waiting list for a guide dog. She has previously been cane-trained by representatives from the charity and is hoping she can get a guide dog soon.Sophie is currently selling raffle tickets for a host of prizes ahead of a a key fundraising event inBallynahinch Masonic Hall on February .Sophie mdash who recently finished in the top six of a SuperValu Superstars competition ndash is keen to help the Guide Dogs charity by raising money on its behalf. She was motivated to help after discovering that it costs pound, to train a guide dog.Cllr Walker, who is no stranger to fundraising for worthy causes, is delighted he will be able to help Sophie support a charity which does not receive any government funding.ldquoI am more than happy to have my head shaved to raise money for Sophie, even though we are still in the depths of winter, he joked.ldquoI hope to raise as much as I can andanyone would like to support me they can contact me via my mobile or social media page. Sophie is on the waiting list for a guide dog and I so hope that she will get one this year.Cllr Walker, who met up with Sophie and her parents yesterday, is encouraging people to give generously and explained that he will be printing a number of sponsor sheets so people will be able to donate.ldquoI have now met Sophie several times and she is very inspirational. My fundraising target is pound and I hope that I will be able to achieve that, he added.Sophiersquos fundraising event in Ballynahinch Masonic Hall on February  featuring live music gets underway at .pm, with the entry fee pound.The winners of ious raffle prizes will be drawn on the night and Sophie hopes the evening will be a great success.Anyone wishing to support Cllr Walkerrsquos sponsored head shave can contact him on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Walsh saves Olympic dream to seal Border Cup
story: RYAN Walsh saved the best for last when Ballynahinch Olympic lted the Border Cup after a sudden death penalty shoot-out at Seaview on New Yearrsquos Day.Victory was no more than Olympic deserved after a rip-roaring and refreshingly open game ended -. The sides were still locked after extra-time and at the end of five penalties apiece when James McClean drilled Olympic - ahead.It was then left to Walsh to break the deadlock when he kept out Ruairi Fitzpatrickrsquos well-struck spot kick to seal victory before he was mobbed by his delighted team-mates.Rathfriland certainly looked the part early doors as they sprayed the ball to both flanks where Fitzpatrick and Thomas Lockhart took full advantage.Fitzpatrick, in particular, ran at Dalton Tate at every opportunity, but Rathfriland failed to take advantage of his wing trickery.The first real shot in anger came in the th minute when Olympicrsquos Anton McGrattan tested Parr, but the big custodian saved with ease.Five minutes later at the other end Dalton Tate produced a telling tackle on the edge of the six yard box to deny Fitzpatrick a certain goal.However, from the resulting corner, Stephen Hughes bundled the ball over the line when Lockhartrsquos delivery caused mayhem.Rathfriland continued to play the ball methodically through the middle where Andy Kilmartin and Hughes were dominant and with  minutes gone they teamed up with Fitzpatrick to carve out another opening for Harry Campbell, but he shot straight at Walsh.Ruairi Cunningham then created an opening for Fitzpatrick, but he was way off target as was Lockhart in the th minute. A minute later at the opposite end Jason Noade got on the end of a McGrattan corner, but headed over.It looked asRathfriland were going to take their - lead into the break as the game entered the th minute and good value they were for their lead.However, with  minutes gone Stefan Mason exploded into le. The rangy striker took on two Rathfriland defenders after picking up a long ball out of defence.He headed down the left flank and looked destined for the by-line, but stopped in his tracks, checked back, turned his markers and curled a lsquoworldyrsquo into the top corner of the net, giving Parr no chance.Two minutes later it was - Olympic and again Mason was involved. When his attempted cross was blocked, McGrattan headed the ball into Nathan Jonesrsquo path.Nothing looked on when Jones got the ball centrally, just inside the box, but he managed to get the ball from under his feet and beat Parr all ends up with a stunning finish and turn the game on its head.The second half was every bit as competitive, but Olympic seemed to have the measure of Rathfriland and were playing well within themselves until Peter Telford was given the freedom of the box and allowed to head in a Lockhart free kick to make it - in the rd minute.Jason Noade then headed a Jones free kick at lsquokeeper Parr and with  minutes played the busy McGrattan fired over after a nice build-up.Another searing run and cross from Fitzpatrick begged to be put away, but Rathfriland lacked a fox in the box and the chance was gone.Chances continued to be created at either end and with the respective lsquokeepers earning their corn with brilliant saves.However, the game was in the nd minute when Walsh came to Olympicrsquos rescue when he somehow kept out an effort from Marty Havern when the former Glenavon striker seemed certain to win the game for Rathfriland. Two periods of extra-time came and went before the dreaded penalty shoot-out took centre stage.Jones, Stevie and Jason Noade, McGrattan, Tate and James McClean netted for Olympic with Kilmartin, Johnny Roy, Nigel Prentice, Ruari Cunningham and Daryll Evans replying for Rathfriland before Walsh saved the day when he beat away Fitzpatrickrsquos penalty.Ballynahinch Olympic: Ryan Walsh, Dalton Tate, Paul Dickson, Jason Noade, Anton McGrattan, Nathan Jones, Stevie Noade, Chris McNamara, Stefan Mason, Conor Reid, Ryan Molloy. Subs: James McClean, Aaron McClean, Shane Murray.Rathfriland Rangers: Jonathan Parr, Graeme Edgar, Ruari Cunningham, Peter Telford, Ruairi Fitzpatrick, Andy Kilmartin, Harry Campbell, Stephen Hughes, Thomas Lockhart, Jonny Roy, Daryll Evans. Subs: Nigel Prentice, Marty Havern, Jonathan Scannell.Ballynahinch Olympic Rathfriland Rangers BORDER CUP FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Workers ‘must not be used as political pawns’
story: HEALTH workers campaigning for better pay and safer services must not be used as a political football, local Unison trade union members have warned.On December , over  Unison members took part in a protest in Downpatrick, braving atrocious weather conditions to send a clear message that all NHS staff working in Northern Ireland deserve pay parity with the rest of their colleagues across the UK.Other trade unions were represented at the recent day of industrial action outside the entrance to the Downshire Civic Centre in Downpatrick, with Unison members on the picket line from am until pm.Local businesses including Molloyrsquos Fish and Chips and Crossgarrsquos a Cafe provided food for the striking staff, with all the trade unions who took part in the industrial action delighted with the overwhelming support they received from the public.This week, Unison has reaffirmed its determination to continue its campaign for pay justice and safe staffing across the whole health and social services system.And they are angry that all those with the power to resolve the dispute have refused to do so, despite agreeing that their cause is just.Unisonrsquos Down Lisburn branch officials Paul McConnelland Marion Ritchiesay that the right of workers to pay parity and safe staffing levels cannot be dependent on the success or failure of the ongoing political talks to restore devolution.They say that the trade union believes that a mechanism to end the current dispute already exists, echoing the view of Unisonrsquos regional secretary, Patricia McKeown, who said the use of health workers as political leverage and the compliance of senior civil servants in that strategy is ldquonothing less than shameful.Mr McConnell and Mrs Ritchie say they hope that the current Stormont talks prove successful, warning that NHS staff must not be used as a political football during this process.The trade union officials are also adamant that industrial action can end ldquoat the stroke of a pen and argue that addressing the staffing levels issue could help reduce hospital waiting lists.ldquoThe industrial action is not just about pay parity with our colleagues in England, Scotland and Wales, said Mrs Ritchie. ldquoIt is also about safe staffing levels. The industrial action involves all NHS staff, not just nurses.ldquoThere is mounting concern that NHS staff are being used as a political football to pressurise the politicians to get agreement on restoring the Assembly. It appears that we are being used as a pawn in a wider political game, but the health and care of patients should be above that.The RCN is planning more industrial action today and again this Friday, with Unison confirming that its members will not be working any overtime on Friday.ldquoOur members are the lowest paid of all in the UK, said Mr McConnell.ldquoEvery time our members take part in industrial action they are losing money. But they feel very strongly about this issue and are prepared to sacrice a dayrsquos pay to make their point. It is important to remember that the ongoing strike is not just about pay parity, it is also about safe staffing levels.Mr McConnell said NHS workers have watched staff leave ious aspects of the service and not be replaced which has left the provision of health and social services at ldquocrisis point with all services affected.He said staff have tended to keep their heads down to deliver services, explaining that they are now saying ldquoenough is enough.The Unison officials said while their members continue to go the extra mile for patients, this is impacting on their physical, emotional and psychological health.Mrs Ritchie added: ldquoStaff family lives are being affected and they have simply had enough, especially as they are being paid thousands of pounds less a year than their counterparts across the water.Mr McConnell added: ldquoThe bottom line is that the goodwill of staff has come to an end. A stroke of a pen can end this dispute and will send a clear message to NHS workers that they are valued and, signicantly, equal to their colleagues across the NHS.ldquoThe pay parity and safe staffing level issues must be addressed now..prettyPhoto
